Far cry 3's best moments are also some of my best moments in gaming, I'll leave my love for this game aside and try be fair evaluating it's aspects. First of all, you can feel the Far cry 2 engine here, similar animations and gunplay, but its definitley improved.  Graphics are pretty, shaders could have been a little less saturated for a more realistic look, but its an art direction choice, still beautiful anyway! I found a few bugs, objects revealing geometry, shadows loading in a weird way and black textures appearing on roads whenever I was nearby, It breaks immersion but don't compromise the fun. Gameplay is fluid, animations are well made, guns feel powerful and there are plenty to choose from your loadout, you can craft boosts from herbs you harvest in the jungle, use a bow that add's a Hunter feel that we all love, and take a stealthy approach if that's your thing, that was something I wasn't sure it would work out well but It did, I finished the game using the knife and bow mostly. Performance is pretty fair, the game runs well if you have a good machine and still pretty even on medium specs, I played this with an GTS450 on medium and then maxed out with a 650ti Boost, running with 40fps most of the time. Story and characters are quite memorable, did I ever tell you the definition of good character design? you got it. After you finish the story you still have activities to complete, hunt & assassination missions, outposts to clear, towers to climb and work your magic to unlock new weapons, it's a very rewarding game and it has lore on every item you acquire. I still have to try the co-op, if you're reading this maybe we should give it a try!?   tl;dr + Open world + Memorable story and characters + Gun customization and variety + Stealth is an option  + Replay value  + Burning weed with Skrillex™  - Minor graphic bugs sometimes - Requires Ubi-Launcher - DLC is Irrelevant and Skippable - Dead multiplayer

Far Cry 3 is a blast! Immersive landscape and environments, living wilderness, lots of enemies and multiple possibilities to take them down. Will you raid a camp Rambo-style, gun-blazing everything and everyone? Will you put C4 bombs on your car and use it to make a diversion? Will you open a cage to release a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tiger on your enemies? Or will you sneak your way through? The choice is all yours.  The story is simple but feels alright, the characters are all pretty charismatic and have their own personalities; the game has humour and dramatic moments. It is beautiful and immersive. The gameplay is varied enough, and when you think it might become boring, new gameplay elements come in. Lots of missions and side-missions to keep you occupied for quite some time; I've played more than 16 hours when I'm writing this review and haven't even finished it yet. Take your time, do some missions, get lost in the jungle, plan your tactics and stop being a prey: be the predator. I only wish the stealth approaches would be more realistic like it was in Far Cry 2, and a better crafting system.  At first I didn't think I'd like this game, but now I love it.  A solid 8.5 or 9/10 for this piece of work.

If you're crashing on Windows 10 after ~15min playing try this out, this is the only thing that fixed it for me  > Click on Windows Start button > Type 'Services'; it'll automatically begin doing a search as you type > Click on the thing that comes up and says, 'Services' > Scroll aaaall the way until you get to 'Touch Input and Handwriting Panel Service' > Right click, click 'Stop' > Enjoy the game!  If in game, it takes forever to 'Log in' to Ubisoft's Fary Cry 3 servers, then fails, and then it does this every time you go to the menu while in game, try either or both of the following:  1. Windows Firewall > Click on Windows Start button > Type in 'Firewall' > Click on Windows Firewall with Advanced Security > On the left column/window, click on 'Inbound Rules' > Scroll on down to the area with a bunch of stuff that says 'Far Cry 3', Far Cry D3D11, etc > Enable all dat jazz  2. Change compatibility of farcry3.exe > Go to whatever hard drive location you store all your Steam games (Folder is called SteamLibrary) > Once in SteamLibrary go to SteamApps, > then common,  > then Far Cry 3, > then bin > For example on my computer the final path looks like this 'E:\SteamLibrary\SteamApps\common\Far Cry 3\bin' > Right click on 'farcry3.exe'  > MAKE SURE its farcry3.exe, not farcry3_d3d11.exe, game will crash on startup if you mess with it > Click 'properties' > A window should pop up with a bunch of tabs on top; click on the 'Compatibility' tab > about 1/4 way down the window it says 'Compatibility Mode' with a little checkbox that says 'Run this program in compatibility mod for:' > Check the checkbox > Select 'Windows 8' from the dropdown menu > Click OK at the bottom of the window > Finally enjoy your god damn game > Oh no wait you have to go through like 10 hoops with Uplay's Google Authentication bullsh!t, where you have to download an app ON YOUR PHONE. You can only have fun after that.

7/10 -What a trip. I enjoyed hunting animals to craft items, Looting, finding relics and completing side missions to get money to upgrade and buy weapons, stealth killing, sniping from a long distance to shoot a cage to let a tiger out of it and watch it maul everyone nearby, taking over enemy posts so I can fast travel to them, fixing towers to show the map and unlock new weapons, running people and animals over with my car, upgrading my character with xp to unlock new moves, starting things on fire and watching it spread and last but not least the story missions. You can craft plants but I ended up not crafting any except green ones which give you health because the rest of the plants you can craft are basically useless. Who wants to craft a plant to allow you to be flame retardant for 15 secs? I didn't care anyway.   Unlike plants crafting animals is useful since you can carry more weapons at a time among other things by collecting their skins. I had fun hunting these animals in the wild and checking my list of how many I needed of a certain breed to create whatever it was. However it was pointless hunting animals anymore after you craft everything unless you want to gain barely any money in doing so or just for the hell of it. Looting dead bodies got really annoying because you have to wait and see the same animation over and over again. There is no way to skip it. Another annoying problem was if their weapon is nearby you have to hover over a certain spot on their body to loot them since you use the same key press to pick up their weapon...why couldn't I just hover over their body and get the loot automatically without pressing anything and press a key if I wanted their weapon? I ended up all the time swapping my weapon accidently because of it.   There is really no death animations just ragdoll physics. Which is disappointing since I liked how in Far Cry 2 you can snipe someones leg and they start yelling in pain from it and if one of their friends is nearby they could pick them up and carry them to safety. You shoot anyone in the leg in this game they just die and fall over. The story was a let down to me. It's really a big lame excuse to kill people on an island. You go to the extremes to save your friends in any situation. I didn't like the main characters voice it was annoying and laughable at the sametime. It doesn't help that your character is a real ♥♥♥♥♥ and makes very poor decisions you have to watch unfold that you don't like. The ending wasn't satisfying at all.   Don't get me wrong though I did enjoy alot of the story missions. The co-op is alright but can be frustrating due to waves of overwhelming odds and connection issues. The motion blur in this game gave me headaches and there is no way to turn it off. I am only nitpicking here but you can't blow up a car or truck by sniping it's fuel tank. You can't cut down trees. You can't blow up a building having it's walls collapse in. You can't fly a helicopter. You can't even see your own feet. It's no Crysis that's for sure but I did have fun and I spent alot of time just wrecking havoc.

Singleplayer : Campaign: I played the campaign on it's hardest difficulty and it took me somewhere around 15 hours. The story is about Jason Brody having a vacation on an island. And wakes up in a cage realising that his vacation is over and he has to save all his friends so they can get back home. This sounds and also felt generic. But as you continue through the game the story gets more and more interesting, due to well voiced characters and the inspiring monologues. The game also felt like some kind of total recall to me, because the character has many drug trips. So even when I was playing the normal sp missions I was asking myself if it wasn't just a drug trip. Because if the bulk of the story was a drug trip the story would make a lot more sense. The campaign story was mostly the reason that kept me playing.   Gameplay: The gameplay other hand was good and entertaining, but nothing special for me. Some early missions could be annoying, because you were forced to play stealthily. Also the sp missions can sometimes feel as a narrow route. The power of the gameplay itself is that you can choose how you want to play. stealthily or guns blazing. Both can be fun but both also have some issues. The stealth problem is that the ai can be annoying. And for guns blazing you can easily run out of ammo and have to break your arm to revive yourself many times if you play guns blazing.(Atleast on my difficulty. I would maybe recommend to play 1 difficulty below or first do a lot of side missions to unlock more health, weapons etc.) Also if you have no ammo you mostly have to camp until you can easily knife someone, without getting hit. Sadly every endboss fight from the game showed the definition of insanity in gameplay. The game was also a bit overwhelming in the beginning because of the many menus with upgrades. At first I ignored them, but later I really saw the benefit of it. Otherwise you will easily die. The graphics of the game still look nice, I especially liked the lighting. And how much effort there had been put into the building.   Open World: I have to be honest I haven't done that much in it. Because I wasn't really interested in it. Still I can say if you are interested in exploring the world there is alot to do! There are enough side-missions, which is mostly killing enemies/animals in a certain way, missions where you have to go from A to B as fast as you can etc and, of course, collecting stuff. Really the only thing that made me stop fast-traveling from mission to missions was the tower climbing and the animal/flower hunt to unlock stuff. They were more rewarding to me than the side missions that just give you money and xp that I already had enough of.    Online :  Multiplayer: In my opinion the mp isn't that special. It has 4 standard game modes. Of course they are varied with some nice ideas. But to me it just feels like a cod-clone. The multiplayer also has a strong map editor. Probably at the time there were many great mods made. (I found some interesting ones on youtube. ) But now that the game isn't as active anymore, I couldn't find a modded map to play. -Co-op: I played the co-op with someone many months before continuing my singleplayer campaign. It was pretty long at 6-8 hours. But still the co-op was pretty generic and forgetable. The only thing that I liked were the mini-games. What is strange is that the multiplayer and the co-op leveling system are combined. So if I had only played Co-Op, I would have all the unlocked loadouts for the multiplayer.    Overall : I can say Farcry 3 is a great game, but you can ignore the multiplayer and co-op, because they aren't that special and that active anymore. I think for the people who only own FarCry 4, FarCry 3 is still a great game to play, especially for the campaign, that makes it something special.

Far Cry 3 spits the naive, arrogant and entitled Jason Brody into a spiralling world of violence, anarchy and survival, beset in a jungle, where survival by whatever means necessary is the norm as he restores order to the islands by takling over pirate camps and towers to reveal a map of the islands.   This is what a first-shooter, open-world game ought to be. Sure, it lacks character development in some scenes, such as Jason's thrust into the island without seeing his emotions unfold as he loses his brother to Vaas. And the main villain: He was really top-notch. Vaas played his role perfectly, though the game mechanics downplayed his role as a vilain. Taking down bosses in choreographed button mashes and simplistic scenes is no way to end a boss. Same went for Hoyt Voyker and Buck Hughes.  All in all, its' many hours of exploration, take-downs, gliding, sky-diving, killing and blowing up things. A journey you'll be begging to return to over and over again.  Second part: Co-Op. That is some awesome stuff. Adds many, many hours of hilarious gameplay and challenge-based system that add up XP , a'la Trials of the Rakyat in Single Player.  Multi-player: Well, this is probably my favorite so far. You can't play it once. Custom maps can also be built and be featured here too.  Notes: Mature content. Everywhere.   Overall rating: 9.5 out of 10.

FarCry 3. One of the BEST games I’ve ever played in my years of gaming. There’s so much to talk about, I guess I’ll divide this game into multiple categories to talk about.  – The storyline 10/10 Words literally how amazingly amazing it felt to play this game. The story mode was well thought out and executed perfectly, an original story with everything else was amazing. I do not wish to spoil the story too much because you NEED to play this game. Basically you are a tourist visiting an island when suddenly something goes wrong…  – The graphics 10/10 Graphic-wise the game is beautiful and detailed, when you’re playing it, it feels like skyrim but with better graphics and more realistic weapons. Sure some computers may not be able to run the game, but the majority of the people who can run the game on the best graphics will admit it you can feel a simple breeze from the wind. The weather system can’t be talked bad about at all because the rain wasn’t too annoying, but was made just perfect.  – The A.I 8/10 The A.I is the only element in the game I could complain about, yet it was marvelous. In times during the game I noticed some A.I glitching in the wall or just auto-noticing me behind a wall. In other times the A.I were just surprisingly professional by avoiding all walls and hiding behind baricades while shooting me only when I stand up to shoot them! Also the A.I of animals was made so they act like they do in real life, from turtles crouching in their shell to sharks slowly getting closer and going in for the kill.  – The Controls 10/10 Everything was designed wisely, starting from the basic-in-every-game controls like WASD and Shift to sprint to smaller details like switching items in your inventory around the way you like.  – The gameplay 10/10 This is the main element of the game which is most essential. The possibilities are infinite, you can play the game as vanilla as you want by using weapons you pick up from the enemy but you can’t taste the game truly unless you’ve tried the RPG’s or the Flamethrower. The leveling up system in the game is not like any other but a very original concept. You unlock new weapons and get them free in shops by claiming land from the enemy or climbing radio towers which noticeably become harder to get on top of with every new one. You can also convert to be a better warrior for the sake of the island by leveling up and getting “Tatau” aka Tattoo’s on your arm which give you abilities like holding your breath underwater longer or decreasing the damage you take from animal bites.  – The Ending 10/10  I really can’t talk much about the ending to not spoil it, but the way you want the game to end is all up to you. There are 2 endings so it’s all up to you how you end the game. – Final Verdict 10/10 The Game as a whole is a 10/10. A First person survival which has more then 30+ Realistic animals. I recommend everyone to play it.

I played this game for seventeen hours straight the first time I sat down and turned it on. I hope that convinces you that this game is great more than it convinces you that I have no self-control or sense of time. I advise anyone who is even remotely familiar with the mechanics of the Far Cry series to play on the hardest difficulty- any less and you'll probably get bored.  In seventeen hours, I am not even close to done with the singleplayer story and have yet to begin playing co-op or multiplayer, but what I have seen so far is amazing. One outstanding feature is Far Cry 3's use of wildlife, which is superb, and miles ahead of its predecessor, in which you would scarecly see any animals at all. While playing this game, I am in constant fear of tigers, sharks, and crocodiles, namely, but there are other animals which range from frightening (cassowaries, they are the spawn of the devil) to irritating (herds of deer darting past). Another improvement over FC2 is the more widespread utilization of fast travel, which was a huge pain and is now endurable. I am more apprehensive about the change in how outposts are managed. Instead of having enemies respawn every time the player leaves the area, guardposts are now on by default, until permanently turned off when the player kills all the guards stationed there.  tl;dr better than FC2 because of combat system, setting, plot, and ANIMALS

Far cry 3 game review. Far cry 3, also known as 'Skyrim with guns.'. There's truth to that, I'll show you in this review.  'Far Cry 3 is an open world action-adventure first-person shooter video game developed mainly by Ubisoft Montreal in conjunction with Ubisoft Massive, Ubisoft Red Storm, Ubisoft Shanghai, and Ubisoft Reflections, published by Ubisoft for Microsoft Windows, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3. The game was released on November 29, 2012 in Australia, November 30 in Europe, and December 4 in North America. A stand-alone expansion titled Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon was released on April 30, 2013.' (-Wikipedia)  In this review, I'll write about a couple of things: -Story -Gameplay -Enemy AI/Boss fights -Crafting -Minigames -Overal Pros and Cons  -Story. The story start out with you, Jason Brody, partying in a club in Bangkok. You're with your brothers, Riley and Grant, and your other friends. Lisa, Daisy, Keith, and Grand. You're celebrating that your little brother Riley got his pilot's licence. The group decides to go skydive over an island. As you land on the ground, you're captured by local pirates, lead by Vaas. All this is shown to you on a phone camera, held by Vaas as you sit in a cel. You and your brother manage to break out of the cel once Vaas is gone. Halfway through you get caught, and have to run. Once you're safely away from the camp, you meet Dennis. And then your mission to resceu your brother and friends begins.  -Gameplay. As previously stated, far cry 3 is an open world first person shooter. There's plently of weapons to pick from. You start out with a knife and a pistol, and as you enable radio towers and do missions, you unlock more weapons. You can also buy weapons from the store, although the prices are fairly high.  There's also skills to be unlocked. One of the first skills you learn is 'take down' , which allows you to take down an enemy with a knife. As you go along, more skills get unlocked. Once you've unlocked a skills, it will be represented by a tattoo on your left arm. The more skills you get, he more the tattoos form a sleeve.   -Enemy AI/Boss fights. I'll admit the enemy AI isn't the best. They'll run for cover, and sometimes try to get away from you, but they'll hardly do anything to prevent getting shot in the open. For example, if you're at a wide open field, they'll run towards you in a straight line. Sometimes they'll seek cover behind an explodable barrel. Overal, it could be improved, but it's not terrible either. Bos fights are often handled in quick time events, much like animals fights. This game also features crafting (Bet you geussed that already!). To improve you have to craft. More storage, more ammo storage, more weapons, more money, and more syringes are some of the things gained by crafting. You can craft multiple sorts of syringes, for healing and combat. There's also syringes for your surrounding, better senses to find animals, holding your breath underwater for longer, and being fireproof.  Syringes are crafted by collecting leaves, the other things are crafted by animals skins.  -Mingames. If you're getting tired from killing pirates and animals, there's also minigames. There are seven of them: Poker (A game of Poker) Racing (Getting from A to B hitting checkpoints) Shooting birds (Shoot birds with a shotgun) Throwing knifes. (Press the button at the right time to throw the knife at the right place on the board) Supply drop. (Get from A to B hitting checkpoints, within the time limit) Wanted Dead. (Kill a pirate with a knife) Hunting qeusts. (Hunt an animal with a specific weapon) All these are unlocked by taking down outposts and activating radiotowers. There's also side mission, all unique.  Overal Pros and Cons. Pros: Fun gameplay Nice graphics, even on low. Large varity of weapons. Good crafting system. Interesting villain (Vaas) Multiplayer (although I've never tried it personally) Lots of Collectables First person driving  Cons: Can get boring if you let it. Second island and villain aren't as interesting as the first. What a massive game this is. Huge islands to explore with just too many sidequests. It's seemingly endless and completing the entire game will take you probably well over 50 hours. Now that's some value right there.  The graphics are just gorgeous, no matter what settings you use. You can't make this game look bad, you just can't. The animations and models are some of the best I've seen in a game. Wow. The same thing applies to the sounds and voice acting, which is brilliant and truly convincing.  While doing the story and sidequests you'll earn XP to upgrade your skills. There are 3 skilltrees in total and the way you play the game is entirely up to you. The Shark skilltree will let you upgrade your assault and healing skills, while the Heron tree will help you with your sniper skills and speed and finally, the Spider tree will let you focus on your stealth and survival skills. TL;DR- Far Cry 3 manages to improve on its predecessor without abandoning most of its basic mechanics. Does have a ridiculous plot that is terribly handled at the end.   I had a love/hate relationship with Far Cry 2. I loved the weapons, the world, and the combat. But I hated the way the place was populated only by people who wanted to kill you on sight (except for in the closed cities). I didn't like the way enemies respawned automatically and the beautiful world was somewhat marred when I couldn't enjoy a senic boat ride without getting sniper fire, even though I'd crushed that outpost five minutes earlier. Unlocking weapons tended to be a bit tedious as well, though it was worth it to get some of the best ones. The mortar in FC2 is one of my favorite weapons in ANY game. It took patience to figure out, but once mastered it could be used to desolate an enemy encampment in dramatic fashion.  FC3 keeps the nice variety of weapons, with the facepalming exception of the above-mentioned mortar. I guess it was unbalancing because of how useful it could be against outposts, but I still wish they had left it in somewhere. Vehicles are still fun, as are boats, plus handgliding is actually a bit more doable in this game- even useful when the game doesn't cheat and turn on the invisible walls for missions. Best of all, not everyone is out to kill you at all times. There are different factions in the game and only MOST want to kill you at any one time! You can actually see battles between the different factions where you can help one over the other. When you take out an enemy outpost, it stays down... unless you decide to revert them back to enemy control so you can have fun blowing them up again- a neat option by the devs to placate both sides of the 'respawning enemies' argument. Plus they've added carnivors. If you remember in FC2 they made some kind of hand-waving statement that they couldn't do that because it would wreck the simulation... or something. Well this time they said 'screw it, add more tigers!' Bravo.   There are a lot of gimmicks in the game. You can blow open the cages of conveniently placed animals to screw with enemies, use hand-gliders or zip lines that just happen to be near enemy outposts, or... all sorts of other stuff that sometimes gets a little old. But there's enough variety that the fun makes up for the head-scratching about why the redshirts don't learn not to leave a man-eating tiger around the middle of their base. There are plenty of unscripted surprises (the first time a croc tries to eat you, for example... happens to everyone) and the whole thing is just a fun romp. The plot... well, I don't really care much about the plot. They botched it a bit by having the sub-enemy be more interesting than anyone else in the game, and there's a lot of trippy psycadelic fight scenes. The free-form part of the game is the draw. There are some RPG elements that really don't need to be there and don't serve much purpose, other than to seemingly check off a box on the list of things every game is supposed to have... but it's not a big deal.  Also a shame is the lack of a day-night cycle as in FC2. It worked so nicely and could have been used to great effect here with easier stealth at night and movement by day, or some other trade-off mechanic. Much of the plot is also nonsensical and a QTE torture scene is so hamfisted I had to roll my eyes when the protagonist looks at his hands afterwards. The whole plotlineis a contrived piece of garbage that could have been solved by your character or his combat-knife equipped buddy just killing the Big Bad who is sitting three feet away and jumping out a window... the same kind of thing you can do at every other part of the game that isn't a cutscene. But instead you have to wait until another QTE-ridden dream sequence... or something... to finish him off. Then have an awful on-rails sequence that, again, makes no sense and seems to be there just to annoy the player. Oh, and combine that with an escort mission. And the escorted person is a moron who seems to purposely get you shot down.   The plot is a necessary evil. The way its handled is... well, an unnecesary evil. Frankly the entire last mission arc is crap. But FC3's island is worth the price of admission... maybe be smarter than I was and just ignore everything after the second island gets unlocked, plot-wise.

FarCry 3 is a great game. The scale of the map, as well as the great combat features and the graphics is in perfect balance.   Let's start with combat. FC3 has a fantastic takedown system. Some takedowns are automatic, like jumping off a ledge and killing an enemy below. Some need more skill, like doing chained takedowns. Of course, you need to unlock these takedowns.  Shooting is fluid and fun, and the satisfaction of ridding an outpost of pirates is a constant fuel to play this game.   Hunting, on the other hand, is fun at first, but there are times when you go to the designated hunting spot only to find nothing is there. This has happened to me numerous times, and even using a Hunting Syringe didn't do squat. Hunting is fun at times, but does become a chore.  As for the story, it is rather generic. A bunch of kids get captured by pirates and one of these kids, a sore loser who was going no where with his life, manages to pick up a gun for the first time in his life, and liberate the islands from the pirates, while the Rakyat (People of the Island) stood around doing nothing.  The vehicles are great fun. The driving mechanics are fantastic! Driving cars through the lush forest, or driving jetskis around hunting for sharks is fun and responsive. The gliders however, are a bit useless and are always difficult to disembark as you always lose health from doing so. \  However, I will say this now. The game lacks guns. There are not enough guns!!! The only guns you get are four or five assault rifles, four sniper rifles and so on. By the end of the game, signature weapons were the only thing I was using (along with a silenced sniper rifle) Also, the main menu feels very clunky and weird. And I wish they had not implemented the loot rucksack in the main menu. It drives me mad, especially when you want to drop unwanted loot, but have to keep clicking it, deleting and clicking yes to delete it.  Graphically, the game is beautiful. Everything from the lush vegetation to the water is really well made and detailed. Explosions look realistic and everything in this game is amazing.  Also, I felt as if they did not use some entities as much as they should. For starters, Vaas only appears a couple of times. At the start, and somewhere halfway into the game. To me, Vaas was a great and interesting character, and they should of used him more. Same thing goes with Hoyt. After reaching the South Island, I was expecting to have a long war dance with Hoyt, only to find that his time as the main enemy is short.   But multiplayer is where this game becomes bad. FC3 multiplayer is AWFUL! It's worse than Blacklight: Retribution, it's worse than COD: Ghosts. It's just a generic, non interesting pirates vs rakyat. Coop is a massive letdown. Instead of having the ability to free roam around Rook Island with your mate, you're pitted in a semi cliche set of linear missions that involve killing tons of pirates. It's ok, and can be quite fun at times, but the worst thing is the BLOODY BOMB CARRYING MISSIONS. Throughout the campaign, there are parts which involve you picking up bombs or rockets and carrying them to certain locations. When you pick one up, you can't sprint, you can't crouch, you can't do ♥♥♥♥ but carry this bomb to its location. It is boring, and a chore especially when your teammate doesn't do ♥♥♥♥ but get downed forcing you to drop the bomb and revive them. It is instantly noticable that Ubisoft just went lazy with the Co-op. After almost an hour of playing through one of the missions, my friend discovered a unique spot where, if you keep running against it, you glitch and fall out of the world, killing yourself in the process. you can also glitch yourself inside Seto's truck by running to its spawn point just as it spawns. The Co-op maps are just poorly made, and are incredibly tedious and repetitive. They also removed the fire spreading system. In Co-op, flamethrowers held by Flamers are OP as hell. But once you have the flamethrower, it does absolutely squat. What was wrong with a free roaming coop mode? Driving around together liberating outposts and ridding the island of pirates.  That sounds far better than the crappy boring coop mode they gave us.  I usually get bored of games very quickly, but I found myself playing this game for hours on end. If you don't want to do the sometimes boring missions, you can always go around liberating outposts, exploring Rook Island and looking for Letters, Relics and so on.  Great game, fun gameplay, great combat system. Don't get this game for its multiplayer.  This is the kind of game where you turn down the in-game music, put on your favourite power songs and play. This is what I did for my second and third playthroughs, and it was amazing! Some of the songs I listened to are forever associated with my killing of pirates! Great experience, one that I won't likely ever forget.  9/10

I digress.  Far Cry 3 is really, really good and interesting and fun. The island is beautiful, the wildlife is interesting, the fire system is more or less intact from the otherwise terrible Far Cry 2 SO THAT'S GOOD and the music is some of my favourite in a long, long time. There's an overwhelming amount of things to see and do, thanks to the scattershot 'world map full of activity markers' Ubisoft school of design, and almost all of it is really fun and usually quite a diversion from the 'routine' gameplay. You probably should anyway.

This game is one of the true cases of real freedom. Not just because it's open world. Not just because ther's lots of things to shoot. And not just because if you get bored you can hurl yourself off a cliff. No, the devs of this game really went the extra mile. For example, the hunting. Yes, you can slowly sneak up on deer before blasting it with a shotgun (if you're boring), or you can grab a flamethrower and molotov cocktails, light a section of forest on fire, and when a bear or pig runs past you trying to escape, you can stab it multiple times in the back. Also, there's a lot of side quests. From finding a missing suicidal teen to seeing how many komodo dragons you can kill with one clip of pistol ammo, there's always something to keep you busy. Also, certain non-essential tasks can help you in the long run. Sure, it may seem boring to climb various towers to reactivate old cell phone beacons, but it'll all pay off when the air fills with smoke and you can still see every one of the dudes you are about to terminate. Which brings me, yes, to the combat. The combat in this game is fantastic, and filled with variety. You can rip a dude's neck out and leave him out to be discovered by already terrified pirates; you can lure over a pack of wild dogs and let Mother Nature do the work. Hell, you can just run up to a guy and beat him over and over with a blowtorch, until he either dies of trauma or lights on fire. A personal favourite of mine was to kill a helicopter pilot while he hovered over an enemy outpost, causing the vehicle to spiral out of control, crushing both the pirates and presumably two or three tigers. Overall, this game gets a solid plus. It's Rambo, Terminator and Tomb Raider squished into one, and I love it. God help me, I love it.

Far Cry 3 is an open world action-adventure first-person shooter video game developed by Ubisoft Montreal in conjunction with Ubisoft Massive, Red Storm Entertainment, Ubisoft Shanghai, and Ubisoft Reflections, published by Ubisoft for Microsoft Windows, Xbox 360, and PlayStation 3. The game was released on November 29, 2012 in Australia, November 30 in Europe, and December 4 in North America. A stand-alone expansion titled Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon was released on April 30, 2013.  Far Cry 3 is set on a tropical island between the Indian and Pacific Oceans. After a vacation goes awry, protagonist Jason Brody must save his friends, who have been kidnapped by pirates and escape from the island and its unhinged inhabitants.  The third installment in the Far Cry series, Far Cry 3 was critically acclaimed upon release, with reviewers praising its world design, open-ended gameplay and story, while the game's multiplayer mode was criticized. Following the game's success, Ubisoft announced a successor, Far Cry 4.

Far Cry 3 has by far reigned among my top 5 open world games, every aspect of this game is great; from the story; to the gameplay; the action, world and its mechanics. You are Jason Brody, a young man looking for an adventure while vacationing on a remote island with your closest friends. Yet you get more than what you bargained for, when your group is kidnapped by drug pedaling pirates to be sold to the underground world of slavery. Now its up to you to save your friends, bring peace back to this once pristine environment, and inspire hope to its native people. As you diverge from your expected path you become a true product of your new environment. You turn from a scared boy, to a ruthless warrior. Though be careful who you trust, for betrayal is lurking around every corner.  This game is like no other, the story missions are long and tough and the side missions are a blast. You must climb to the top of hundred foot radio towers to acquire maps, radar and weapons; liberate pirate outposts; learn the lay of the land; hunt its native creatures, both docile and ferocious; find its most precious and scarce relics; bounty hunt for the islands most wanted; and test your skills through vigorous timed trials. This enormous world has more than enough ways to spend your time. If you feel like taking a break from the fighting, go play some poker, place wagers on your marksmanship, throw knives, get laid, or race ATVs.  As you delve in to this chaotic world, you find all resources at the palm of your hand. Customize your weapons by adding scopes, extended magazines and suppressors. You can pick someone off from a mile away, shoot them in the back with your bow and arrow, slit someone's throat, or blow it all up! Every desirable weapon is available at your disposal; hand guns, shotguns, assault rifles, SMGs, LMGs, RPGs, C4 explosives, knives, even a f**king flamethrower; everything your twisted heart could desire! The question is, how will you save this world? As a silent assassin, or a gun toting juggernaut?  Choose who you wish to become by picking skills from three separate skill trees. You can chose to become a stealthy assassin, a long range killer, an unstoppable killing machine or all three. Will you learn how to shoot from a zip line, or how to silently ambush numerous enemies from atop and below? These skill will also help you become a better hunter-gatherer. Collect indigenous plants to craft potent remedies and abilities or learn to silently hunt a tiger or shark for its hide.  Like any good contemporary game, there is multiplayer along with coop. Fight with or against players across the world to complete objectives, sabotage each other's bases, go on missions, or just shoot each other up in death match. Be careful though, for the losing teams best player is to be made an example of. The winning team can chose to show mercy, or beat him to within an inch of his life.   So mount up! This world cannot be saved without your efforts. Just remember, trust no one. Not even yourself...

An almost perfect Open World FPS with crafting and RPG elements. The story is amazing and the acting/voiceover work is probably the best I've ever seen in a game (the guy who plays Vaas is incredible. Best villain EVER). The thing that impressed me most about this game is, you don't have to spend hours of your time crafting an sorting through piles of junk, trying to determine what to keep and what to sell or discard. Junk is easily 'quick sold' and is explicitly marked as junk so there's no need to feel like you should hold onto it until later in the game when it may come in handy. The only real items of importance when it comes to crafting are animal skins for capacity upgrades (i.e., how much stuff you can carry) and plants for crafting medicines and buffs.  Leveling and stat trees are balanced and easily managed. It's possible to gain every skill in the game in a single run through so you don't have to feel like you missed out or ruined your game by taking one skill point over another. Just simply farm up some more XP and get that skill as well.  Finally, the graphics are beautiful, even if a bit aged. It's very easy to get totally submersed in the game with the wonderful graphics and beautiful locations, especially considering how great the story is and how amazing the voice and acting talent are (did I mention that Vaas is incredible? Because if there were ever Oscars given to video game actors, he should be the first to receive one). The options menu is deep and extremely configurable, from key layouts to graphics and sound settings. I have a pretty basic bargain-bin laptop (Acer Aspire E 15) with no modifications running the integrated intel HD 4400 with 1792 VM and can get the game to run with a bit of lag at full settings. I run mostly on medium with a few settings set to high, however, and get a constant frame rate of ~30fps (which is great for my non-gaming computer).  My only gripe with this game is the soundtrack. It's pretty bland and bear-bones and neither adds nor subtracts from the game. It's just kind of 'there'. It doesn't hinder the experience in any way but I feel with a stronger score or maybe even the addition of some licensed music added during key scenes, it could have added that much more to the submersive experience.  Overall, this game is a 9.5 out of 10 which by my grading standards, is practically a 10. I save 10s for the absolute best of the best. Games that not only are damn near perfectly designed and executed and fun to play, but which have also changed the landscape of gaming in general and paved the way for others to follow. The only '10's I've played I can count on 2 hands (Super Mario 3 and Super Mario World, The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past and Ocarina of Time, Half-Life II, Tetris, Mrs. Pac-Man and maybe a few more I'm forgetting). Far Cry 3 is almost there but, there isn't much here that hasn't already been done before. That said, everything about the game that came from other games, Far Cry 3 put it all together and made it better as a whole than anyone else in it's genre. They took the best parts of games like Borderlands and Fallout and improved upon them in a way that's damn near perfect.

Introduction:

This game is an exact cross between Far Cry and Far Cry 2. For those that don’t remember, Far Cry was the first game (afaik) which allowed players to hide in shrubs on a massive tropical island with luscious green foliage. It used the first Crytek game engine. In Far Cry 2, you couldn’t really hide in shrubs, instead you were placed on a barren African landscape wearing a straw hat and on safari. This time the Dunia game engine was used which I’d personally say is more than just a heavily modified version of the CryEngine.  Far Cry 3 uses the Dunia Engine 2. What this means is, the gameplay mechanics and overall feel of the game will be more like Far Cry 2. This is particularly noticeable with the shooting mechanics, the openness of the landscapes with trails/tracks/villages/compounds and even the driving of boats and vehicles will feel pretty much the same. Except the only difference is you’re on a luscious island where you have plenty of shrubs to hide in (or burn lol).  What’s different? We get a pretty full on cinematic experience. It almost felt personal with the characters being so close and their faces taking up the entire screen. I thought they all wanted to kiss me. Aside from that, I thought all characters were standup comedians. Vaas in particular, but Buck as well. They have hilariously crazily loveably outrageous personalities.  There is also an XP skill system in place. It didn’t bother me (see my Hitman: Absolution review) but after a year I’m now growing to hate seeing this in games. Not only is it a lame way to track progress, I reckon it damages the RPG genre. But like I said, it wasn’t much of a bother in this game.  Overall Far Cry 3 in my opinion is for those that seek a very slow-paced game where you complete menial tasks on the island, but with the goal of exploration. Having said that, the island is a work of art, very detailed at every place. Not just a piece of terrain where they plopped buildings and 3D models on randomly.  It’s interesting seeing how the land mixes in with the river banks, tree roots, erosion and sediments. Like you’ll see some tin shack on some beach in the middle of nowhere with intricately placed shore rocks, or you may walk through a plain field of grass with some oak-like trees during the night, or a lake in the middle of nowhere, it’s an experience to remember.  I can almost certainly guarantee you that you won’t traverse the same spots on the island more than twice. This can be proven by purchasing maps to display the locations of all the loot chests. There’s a crap load of them! And for about 30 hours I was really nitpicky in the beginning opening those chests.  The game was a bit buggy for me from time to time, but I always seemed to pull out of it without losing too much progress. Like sometimes you can bypass waypoints with ease which will break the mission. I also didn’t like long unnecessary animations like patting corpses for loot. Sometimes the game would just crash when I sell a lot of loot items in the store. I run an AMD 5000+ overclocked to 3GHz and HD6870. This is a pretty old gaming rig and I was able to play on high settings comfortably enough (felt like 25-30 fps when running).  I prefer Far Cry 2, but Far Cry 3 is a very sophisticated game technology-wise. Definitely a step forward that newcomers can jump into without needing to play the predecessors since the stories and characters are all different.  *note this review was cut down from 9000+ words.

Uplay first, then game review.  As many other reviews pointed out, this game uses UPlay. I don't like that it uses uplay because I bought the game through Steam and would like to play it only through Steam. But as long as it's fast going through their servers and isn't a complete nuisance to sign on, whatever.  However, the first time I tried to play this it took me a ♥♥♥♥ing HALF HOUR to get in the damn game. At first it said uplay's servers were busy or offline, which took a while. I thought 'Ok, fine, I'll play offline. No big deal.' Guess what?! You CAN'T play offline the first time you run the game. So I HAD to go through their servers. When they were finally accessible, I got the Uplay captcha puzzle, which involved putting a single set of numbers from a single picture into two boxes. The rules: One box cannot be blank. The number cannot be copied into both boxes. The numbers cannot be split up. Think the audio captcha will help you out? It specifically says not to put spaces in, then says one set of numbers. Refreshing the captcha didn't help, I kept getting the same damn problem until I found one that had a letter tacked onto the end of the numbers which I put into the other box, and it finally worked. At this point I was pretty mad, I just wanted to play my ♥♥♥♥ing game and instead I'm wasting time trying to figure out the impossible captcha.  From this point on it was easy to log in, the only other problem I had was that at one point my game stopped syncing, so when my SSD got scrambled (uplay decided to install itself on my windows drive instead of my programs drive), I lost half my progress. I also didn't know it at the time, but I wasn't getting achievements for storyline events. When I played through them again, I got them. So back up your saves, guys!  FINALLY, THE GAME  The game feels very much like the new Tomb Raider except more open. I also got a few fleeting feelings of Assassin's Creed. Like how it feels to play those games? You'll probably like this one. There's a wide variety of weapons and I like that you can get a lot for free by unlocking towers. Going hunting is actually good for something, as you use it to craft holsters, rucksacks, etc.  The story didn't impress me at first, nor the character development, but I'm liking it much more now. I only wish there were more conversation opportunities with your friends! They all seem very one-dimentional, with the exception of Daisy, who just seems much more nuanced in her words and expressions. I will update this as I finish the game, 3 missions to go.  The graphics are great, albeit a bit repetative (but they are on an island, so... lots of palm trees are to be expected, I guess). A few problems where I see black/blue shapes but nothing terrible or constant. Sometimes characters vibrate, which makes it ridiculously hard to snipe.  Controls are great for the most part, the problem I have is when performing special actions. When I'm climbing a radio tower, stepping onto the very edge, and see ropes where 'climb' should appear...it doesn't. I can wiggle one way or the other and sometimes it shows up, sometimes not. So I can jump and sometimes have the game catch me and climb up, or I can fall to my death and start over. Annoying. More annoying is when I'm sneaking around an enemy camp like a boss, killing people, when I sneak up behind someone and the 'takedown' option doesn't appear. Again, I move around, sometimes it works. Most of the time though they either turn around and alert the whole camp, or I slice but don't kill them and they alert the whole camp.  Open world, lots of places to explore even if climbing towers and liberating camps gets boring. Can't wait to see how it ends.

I rarely play these kind of big budget, AAA games, but I saw this on sale and decided to gave it a whirl. I'm glad I did.  The game is a wild ride, with a large variety of over-the-top vehicles, gadgets & weaponry at your disposal. The voice acting and dialogue are first grade, comparable to what you'd get in a first-rate action film.  The combat and stealth are implemented quite well, despite an overreliance on QuickTime events. Those QT events make the game feel very 'console' at times. Veteran gamers will know what I mean. It's hard to really *lose* here.  The story is compelling and well told, despite the protagonist being a typical Joe Sixpack American-type. The villains are some of the most outrageous and cruelly entertaining I've ever seen in any video game. There are also some brilliant sections simulating drug-induced hallucinations that reveal a great depth of creativity.   Be warned, you have very little control over the plot of the game. The only real chance to influence the plot comes at the game's very end.  Highly recommended, if you can get past the highly scripted nature of the game and ignore its clear console origins.

I just finished this game and I liked it a lot, but there were problems. Some were just annoying, like how when I climb a ledge, I am grabbing the air 6 inches away from the ledge or how if I got a phone call before getting a main mission, I'd have to hear it every time I loaded the game or completed a side mission.  The best part was combat. The enemies in the first half of the game are easy to hide from until you start shooting. In the second half, they will see you better, but you are wearing their uniform so they won't be hostile until you are, or if you go into a restricted area. My only problem with combat was that if I miss with the bow, the enemies know where I was shooting from, but if you hit, they didn't seem to know. What made it great though is how the enemies rally and more will come once you start making noise. What seems like an easy fight against two enemies can quickly become a fight against 6, coming from different directions.  This game fixes a problem I had with FarCry 2. In FC2, I was annoyed that to get anywhere easily, I had to drive through several outposts which were constantly manned by enemies that respawned rather quickly. There were not multiple sensible ways to get somewhere. Here, there are enemies around and you have to be careful, but there are choices, such as driving on or off road, or walking over hilly terrain. You also don't keep fighting enemies in the same spot every time. However, there is one big problem. There are these enemy controlled outposts throughout the island. They are avoidable, so they don't have the problem FarCry 2 had. However, while clearing them is fun, especially trying to go undetected, clearing the outpost makes the area 'safe' meaning the tribe you are helping takes over. Now you will have allies in the area instead of enemies. The problem is that this makes those areas boring as there is no longer a threat. It also breaks my immersion. Where were all these fighters before? If the pirates have complete control of the island, why do they never take these outposts back?  There is actually some story justification for why you go quickly from inexperienced and afraid to a killing machine. It may or may not be enough for you, but it's something.  This was the first open world game I was able to stick with my attempt to not use fast travel. The world is big, but unless you are going from one end to the other, you don't feel like it takes forever. The island is beautiful and they really did great work and put in many detailed areas. The relics are meaningless collectibles, but they are worth collecting to see the locations where they are hidden. The Letters of the Lost, letters written by Japanese soldiers from WWII, were interesting and worth finding.  Finally, most of the side missions were fun. The supply runs were a blast because they make you drive over crazy terrain, not just a road. The Wanted Dead missions were also cool and requiring a knife kill made several difficult. However, some of the hunting missions are stupid, such as when you are asked to 'hunt' rapid dogs with an RPG or flamethrower. That's the Path of the Warrior?  The main antagonist, Vaas was one of the best I've seen. They do a great job of exploring if your character is actually becoming like his enemy. However, they deal with him in a really stupid way. Basically, he beats you in cutscenes several times throughout the game. After one of these times, you go into what seems like a dream state where you fight him. You have no reason to think anything about it is real, but you wake up and are told Vaas is dead. That's it. Lame.   Edit: The story justification is actually really good, but it is horribly unsatisfying from a gameplay perspective.  The last problem is that the ending gives you a choice despite there being no choices to make during the course of the game. One seems to fit, but the other makes no sense and you have absolutely no reason to choose it. It's as if they tried to give you a Star Wars dark side option, or a choice like the original Fable. However because there were no morality choices throughout the game, it didn't fit. Also, something happens that made me want revenge. I have never wanted to storm an enemy camp and kick ♥♥♥ more than I did at he end of this game, but it didn't let me.  Overall, I do recommend it. It was fun, but there are problems that keep it from being great. 7/10

The Far Cry series has done what so few others have in that each game has redefined our perception of what this franchise is. The first game had you blasting through a Island of Dr. Moreau-inspired landscape, the second brought us back to reality with a hunt for an arms dealer in Africa, and now the third installment aims for a more personal experience while drawing inspiration from films like Taken and Turistas.  In the game you play as an American 20-something year old named Jason Brody who accompanies his two brothers and wealthy friends on vacation in Thailand. Being thrill seekers and adrenaline junkies the group is told about Rook Island where 'anything goes' and they decide to blindly sky dive onto it. Shortly after landing the group is taken captive by pirates led by the clearly sadistic and violently insane Vaas who plans to collect a ransom but sell them into slavery anyway. After narrowly escaping, Jason is taken in by the local natives who inpsire him to take the fight to Vaas and save his friends.  The story is beautifully crafted, the characters are vivid (thanks to phenomenal voice acting and animation), and the game's use of insanity as a focal point pays off brilliantly.  Like the previous titles, FC3 drops the player in an open environment that's just as big if not bigger than Skyrim and all of it save a smaller island is available to explore from the get-go. Populating the game world are story missions, side missions, and hidden collectibles and transportation including cars, trucks, boats, ATVs, hang gliders, and jet skis. The combat is exciting and tense and a large arsenal of weapons is at the players' disposal covering handguns, SMGs, assault rifles, LMGs, sniper rifles, shotguns, and even a bow and flamethrower.   While the story missions are always varied and great fun the side missions are repetitive and lack luster after awhile. Tracking down hidden collectibles also becomes a chore pretty quickly as the payoff for doing so is limited. Lastly while the environment looks incredibly appealing it does become stale after awhile in its lack of variety. Additionally, some of the more detail oriented players have noticed that the game world lacks some of the awesome physics and destruction features present in the PC version of Far Cry 2.  Overall though the pros greatly outweigh the cons. Far Cry 3 is a tense and brilliantly designed game that is totally worth picking up. If you're looking for something that seamlessly blends a fantastic narrative and addictive gameplay look no further. Personally I can't wait to see what they do with the next game and how the franchise will redefine itself again.

Far Cry 3 improves upon its predecessor in almost every way. The map, while still large, does not feel arduous to cross. There is much to see and do on every journey and the fast travel system means you spend more time in firefights and less time driving along empty roads.  The first half of the game gets a little repetitive. Liberate outpost, capture radio tower, complete side missions, rinse repeat. It is in the second half, however, where everything comes to life. The story explodes into a fantastic series of story and mission quests that build towards a very enjoyable finale. Side missions are still available and the path of the hunter quests are worth doing until equipment is fully upgraded. Sadly there is little reason to seek the hidden items apart from a minor experience boost for doing so.  The unique skills in the tattoo tree add some variety but the opportunities to use them are few and far between. More often than not you’ll find yourself picking off enemies with an assault rifle or sniper and then cleaning up with a shotgun or SMG.  One of the best aspects of Far Cry 3 are the rich characters. They have unique personalities that really stand out and give richness to interactions and their parts in the larger story. The best of these is Citra, the alluring and slightly unstable leader of the Rakyat. The contrasts drawn between her and Vaas add some entertainment between missions.  The crafting system in FC3 is accessible and the items created are very useful. Syringes provide valuable boosts and abilities and it is wise to keep a full stock at all times.  Overall I look back at the experience fondly and will remember some of the moments and action sequences for some time to come. Bravo!

This game is easily one of the (if not THE) greatest single-player FPSes I've ever played. (There is multiplayer, but you don't need to know that. Seriously, don't bother.)  Everything falls just right in this game; hunting animals to craft larger rucksacks, wallets and ammo pouches is fun (complete with certain equipment that can't be crafted without sidequest-specific animal hides), shooting feels just inaccurate enough with assault rifles, explosions feel explosiony, fire is gorgeous, water is gorgeous, and there are SO MANY WAYS to take on enemy outposts (from brute force, to range, to stealth, and even sneaky trap-setting).  However, one detail sets this game apart for me:  The sound.  I don't mean the music, or the way footsteps fall, or any bitrate magic; I mean a very specific thing:  Echoes.  You see, when a gun fires, someone shouts, a car accelerates, or an animal roars and you are at a distance, a magical echoing effect is applied to the sounds, and there's something whimsical to hearing it. Allow an example:  You're bearing down on your targets, safe in a cliffside. They have no clue a sniper is looking down on them. You shoot, and one falls without notice. Another. Another. But maybe you miss, or shoot the fourth guy in the leg, or someone turns around and sees his body fall down. Suddenly the outpost is in panic, men scream and shout, firing their guns at things that aren't there. Then one spots you, and you hear his call of 'I SEE ONE!' ring out across the air. All this sounds cool, but as I said before, hearing it with echoes is truly something  else .  Oh but Uplay is taped on to the game.  9.99/10 - The rating level I reserve for Far Cry 3 because it is a perfect game that is hindered slightly by Uplay.

Just finished the game. It was my first time playing the Far Cry series and I must say, what a trip. Jason came a a tourist but somehow becomes an excellent gunman, explosives expert, master offroad driver, hunter, assassin, alchemest, spalunker, and ♥♥♥♥s one of the natives in a matter of weeks.   It's a great game.   The gameplay itself is fantastic. An open sandbox world, a world bright and tropical but I could never seem to relax knowing a pirate squad could come driving up any second. I could run around and do many different things. I could collect ingrediants to craft syrums, hunt animals for there skin and craft better quality gear, or just run around taking outposts and fixing cell towers so I could get money and afford to upgrade my weapons. The map itself is expansive, and challenging to trek without proper vehicle. When trekking an enemy could be just waiting for you over the hill, and it maybe a tiger or a bear or some ♥♥♥♥ like that. The firefights in this game get intense, and the more you go on the more intense they get. With all of thise comes experience points, these points earn you a new skill in the tree which come in really handy because they actually design the map around these skills, the more skills you have the easier it is to do things on the island, including kicking pirate ♥♥♥. I spent hours at a time playing this game emersed in it's world and it was easy to slip into the charact of Jason Brody.   The story is pretty good. Ammo is very limited as well, and you have to restock your supply every so often by returning to an outpost or store, or looting it from a dead pirate.   Overall this game is only a hanful of games I've cared enough to complete in the last few years. To me, that means alot.   I give this game 9 out of 10 MF Falco's.

I played the original Far Cry and found it to be a game of lackluster storyline and glorious graphics. I player Far Cry 2 and found it to be annoying, repetitive and boring, yet nice-looking. So that's what I expected from Far Cry 3 as well.  I was wrong.  Far Cry 3 is pretty, that much hasn't changed. In fact the game was so pretty that all the pretty environments, visual effects and bright colours actually made me feel physically ill sometimes, which I guess has to count against the graphics, but other than that Far Cry 3 is a gorgeous game.  However, unliked it's predecessors, Far Cry 3 has an interesting premise, that of young adults captured by pirates and struggling to escape with the assistance of native resistance warriors fighting the pirates. It has cool locations, characters and missions, and most importantly: it has an arc. The protagonist, Jason Brody, changes throughout the game. He grows on you in this weird way, and I found it unusually easy to relate to him.  The voice actors are solid, the game uses original and lifted music effectively and most of the sound effects seem top-notch.  And then there is the positive surprise! While most modern games give you something between 6-10 hours of gameplay, Far Cry 3 got me up to 22 hours, with easily 90% of the side missions untouched and much of the map still left to properly explore. If you are that kind of a person, you can easily get lost in this game and just roam the land, hunting prey, be it man or animal, and taking in the glorious scenery.   I didn't expect to, but I truly recommend this game.   Playtime: 22+ hours (single playthrough)  Ratings (1-10) Visual: 8 Audio: 9 Story: 8 Gameplay: 9 Overall: 8

I feel as if a recommendation of this game would make me seem like I am high, much like a lot of the game to be exact, cause EVERYONE says this is a brillient game. Its kind of surreal really, because for a game that recieved such high critical acclaim, and was so popular and FPS like, I actually genuinely liked it as an FPS.   Not because of the RPG mechanics, or the inclusion of crafting, gun variety, character development, decent main story, trippy topics like drug use, and abuse, piracy, and slavery. Well I liked all of those actually, but the shoot-em-up sections were fun. The game managed to keep a consistent tone, and actually develop itself over the course of time, in a meaningful way. It created that open world magic of going out to a location, and taking it down with your acculated ability, and weapons, but this is where is starts to fray.  Because at its core, its an FPS, its no Skyrim with guns, because thats Fallout. FC3 fails not on a fundimental level, but on an auxillery one, whereby, its not fun to explore without a solid objective, or tangible reason to be exploring. The island is just bland, empty really, sure it looks nice, but there is nothing secret to explore that cant be found by buying a loot map from stores. The game turns from that open world fun, to another rather linear progression of 'go here, get new gun, do story mission to unblock this set of new skills'. The game tries to pace a open world game, and that does not mesh well. As well, it is incredibly easy, and more deaths will be attribute to poor design, rather than lack of character skill, or weapon balence. In other words, there is more of a case of rage quit deaths, than real honourable ones.  Now dont get me wrong, even though I just spent the last 157 words bashing the game, I still think it is brillient. I would recommend it to anyone that wants an easy shooter, that would like to have a rather relaxing and enjoyable experiance like me.

With the 130 hours in mind, I can safely say this game is absolutely amazing. Far Cry 3 was a major development from the first 2 games, and has become without question, my most favourite game of all time. Far Cry 3 explores various themes, and carries quite an incredible storyline that is deceptively dark and powerful, even if the initial plot is very simple. I've played through Far Cry 3 at least 4 times, on every difficulty and tried different endings and choices. The first time I finished the game was by far, the most moving ending I've experienced in any game. It has great replayability, even after finishing Far Cry 4 I come back to this for the memories and unique gameplay. With amazing graphics, a gripping storyline, and such realistic gameplay, I still recommend Far Cry 3 today. I will never forget my time with Far Cry 3, it was the best experience I've ever had the pleasure to be part in. The map editor probably kept me entertained for months, and while I never played much co-op, what I did play was pretty fun. I personally prefer Far Cry 3 over 4, as it just feels more magical and special. I only hope that Far Cry 5 will return to the brutal and beautiful atmosphere that Far Cry 3 had, without completely redoing it (cough cough Far Cry 4).  So yes, Far Cry 3 is still worth every cent (and probably more to be honest). It still remains my most favourite game ever, and will for a very long time. Don't hold back on getting it, It's an unforgettable journey.

After spending 90+ hours completing everything there is to do in Far Cry 3, I can safely say I haven't had this much fun in an FPS for a long time. Having the freedom to do practically anything you like, in any order you like, in any style you like, is a refreshing change from the standard-fare modern military shooter. I had so much fun doing things like, when needing a vehicle, popping a jeep driver with my Desert Eagle .50, watching the jeep slide up a hill, flip over a few times, kill the gunner in the roll, and then land perfectly upright on the road in the direction I needed it. Thank you very much!  However, the game does have a few caveats - firstly, it's as buggy as all hell, even today. Crashes to desktop on buying/selling items, restarting mission/quest checkpoints, or just entirely randomly while running around is worryingly common, so save often. I even fell through the ground and out of the world on the wingsuit once.  The UI and save system is also somewhat irksome and could've been implemented better on PC (an unfortunate leftover of the inferior console version), and the cash limitation is absurd - once you've bought all the weapons, upgrades and paint jobs, the only way to spend your wallet is to deliberately burn ammo and get yourself injured to buy armour/medicine. Not a game-breaker by any means, but annoying for a completionist like myself who wants to loot every chest, but can't because of an arbitrary cash limit - it just doesn't need to be there.  Finally, there are one or two poorly-balanced story missions that can be very difficult to complete unless you metagame it and do things like lay mines with advance knowledge of enemy spawn positions (Huntley and the plane repairs, I'm looking at you!). The plot could've done without some of the trippy, mystical stuff as well.  Despite a fair few misgivings, though: overall decent shooting, interesting world, plenty of free-form fun, and some intriguing and dark characters make for an enjoyable game. Just don't expect it to be perfect.

Far Cry 3 improves upon its predecessor in almost every way. The map, while still large, does not feel arduous to cross. There is much to see and do on every journey and the fast travel system means you spend more time in firefights and less time driving along empty roads.  The first half of the game gets a little repetitive. Liberate outpost, capture radio tower, complete side missions, rinse repeat. It is in the second half, however, where everything comes to life. The story explodes into a fantastic series of story and mission quests that build towards a very enjoyable finale. Side missions are still available and the path of the hunter quests are worth doing until equipment is fully upgraded. Sadly there is little reason to seek the hidden items apart from a minor experience boost for doing so.  The unique skills in the tattoo tree add some variety but the opportunities to use them are few and far between. More often than not you’ll find yourself picking off enemies with an assault rifle or sniper and then cleaning up with a shotgun or SMG.  One of the best aspects of Far Cry 3 are the rich characters. They have unique personalities that really stand out and give richness to interactions and their parts in the larger story. The best of these is Citra, the alluring and slightly unstable leader of the Rakyat. The contrasts drawn between her and Vaas add some entertainment between missions.  The crafting system in FC3 is accessible and the items created are very useful. Syringes provide valuable boosts and abilities and it is wise to keep a full stock at all times.  Overall I look back at the experience fondly and will remember some of the moments and action sequences for some time to come. Bravo!

“Did I ever tell you the definition of insanity?”  Gamers, if you’re fans of first-person shooters or sandbox games, buy Far Cry 3. Buy it right now. Really, go ahead, I know Steam is open. You're reading this on it right now. I’ll wait. Squared away? Good.  Allow me to start by saying that there's a very good reason for Far Cry 3 to be called the 'Skyrim of action games.' Ubisoft Montreal put together a blockbuster with this colorful descent into a surreal and bloody madness, departing refreshingly from the bland letdown that was the game’s predecessor.  The game’s action elements are solid, boasting tight, well-polished shooting, simple and intuitive driving controls, and a suitably varied array of ♥♥♥-kickery available to players. Its pseudo-RPG elements are also pleasantly deep for an FPS game. The iterative augmentations to players’ melee and stealth abilities are particularly noteworthy, as each is often more brutally satisfying than the last, serving as fitting rewards for players, and as visceral illustrations of the main character's transformation from stranded adrenaline junkie to primal killing machine. Each ability’s visual representation as a part of an increasingly intricate series of tattoos along Jason’s forearm is a nice touch of artistry and immersion as well.   Between these abilities and Far Cry 3’s limited but effectual weapon customization options, it’s this potential for personalization that allows players to gradually carve out their own play style in Far Cry 3’s organic and flexible combat system. One may select increasingly potent health boosts, and pack a shotgun and a fistful of grenades for wrecking pirate faces. Another may opt for a more stealthy approach, relying instead upon knife takedowns, silenced guns, and environmental hazards to distract and dispatch enemies.  Like bears. In no other game may you make tactical bear-strikes. Developers, get on this. Now.  An additional co-op mode, complete with its own story arc, alongside a fairly standard competitive multiplayer mode, keep Far Cry 3’s long-term entertainment value afloat, offering multiple gaming experiences under one digital roof. That said, it’s worth noting that the game’s multiplayer modes don’t allow for near the customization or freedom as that of the single player experience, though that’s to be more or less expected. The gift that keeps on giving, however, is Far Cry 3’s admirably user-friendly map editor, which its player base has taken to creating some creative arenas with.   Sadly, Pokerface Deathmatch is not one of them.  On the technical end of things, Ubisoft obviously took their time with coding and QA testing this title. Even on mid-level gaming rigs, Far Cry 3 runs with admirable efficiency, and it’s a real treat on more powerful systems. Even on consoles, the game is gorgeous in every aspect of its presentation, from its smooth graphics and diverse soundtrack, to say nothing of the actors’ stunning performances. Regarding the latter, my hat is way, way off to Michael Mando for his performance as Vaas, the game’s first and most memorable antagonist.   The standout flaw of Far Cry 3 is that there simply isn’t enough of it. The single-player story is rather short, ends abruptly, and doesn’t have much replay value. Side missions will only last players so long, and once players clear regions of enemies, there’s no real sense that their victories are ever in jeopardy. Once you’re finished with an area’s tasks, there’s just not much reason to go back. This, coupled with the patronizing hand-holding of the game’s map function keeps Far Cry 3 from really capitalizing on the dangerous wonder of its setting.   In all, Far Cry 3 looks, feels, and plays like a startlingly entertaining amalgamation of standard FPS fare, Assassin’s Creed, and Skyrim, and damnit, I want more. Farcry 3 does a lot of things right and a few things wrong.   Let's start with the positives. The sandbox open world is absolutely beautiful. It's massive, it's lush, and you'll always see the islanders out and about doing things so it really gives the world a sense of life. Out of curiousity, I turned my graphics settings down to low and the game still looked pretty damn good. I wasn't much of a fan of the music in the game, as most of it was very basic beats, but the ambient noises are excellent and you'll always have that paranoid feeling when you hear that tiger growl off in the distance, not knowing whether it's coming after you or just passing by.  Now the negatives. The side missions can be quite repetitive. They fall into the formula of 'Go hunt this animal or Kill this guy with a knife or deliver these supplies before the time runs out.' It was hard for me not to get bored at times doing the side missions, because I've already done some redition of previously. The main campaign was pretty good. Not excellent, not just okay, but somewhere in between. The story has a lot to be desired but luckily it's held up by an excellent voice actor cast.   The crafting and skill system is pretty cool. My only complaint is I had a tendancy to have all my skills filled before the next set would open up, which is dependent on your main story progression. So there would be times where I would have 3-4 skill ponts I couldn't use because the additional skills were still locked because I hadn't made it that far in the story yet.  The game has a few quirks, but overall was a very enjoyable experience. If your a completionist, then there are tons and tons of things for you to collect and complete. Playing just through the main story took me somewhere along the lines of 18(ish) hours, but if you strive to do everything, I would be surprised if you could easily get 35+ hours of gameplay. I recommend Far Cry 3 who like first person shooters and sandbox worlds. There is tons for you to explore and story will keep you interested(just perhaps not on the edge of your seat).  I am giving the Far Cry 3 an 8/10.
