Come the white savior and face your insanity through substantial substance abuse.  There are a couple of improvements from the last game, such as no more re-spawning enemies at checkpoints, NO MORE MALARIA SHOTS, more advanced upgrade system, better presented faction war, more meaningful exploration, more open world (instead of labyrinth-like ravines of Far Cry 2), etc.  The story:  You play as a rich white guy who probably never worked a day in his life and who came to the island with his friends and family to relax, jump out of airplanes and be 'the king of the world'. Short time after you and your buddies get captured and butt ♥♥♥♥♥ by a pirate named Vaaaaaaaas. Eventually, after escaping, you find out that you possess magical-primal-instinct-killer-powers which you develop and which enable you to kill pirates, run for miles without stopping, rescue your friends (or whoever is left) and liberate the dark-skinned native population on the island who accept you as one of their own and eventually come to revere your mere presence. Typical White Savior theme, it's kind of sickening. Dances with the Wolves, Avatar, Blood Diamond, The Last Samurai, anyone?  The graphics:  The graphics are okay despite the fact that this is one of the few games to fully utilize quad core processors. The jungle is static: no vegetation moves on the island because there is no wind (except for when it's raining), the waves always move though. . There's some destructibility but not much. The field fires are back though which is good. The drawing distance kind of sucks though, there's this constant distance blur and it gets even worse when you are hand-gliding. It just doesn't look crisp or sharp enough so it kind of hurts your eyes, aesthetically speaking. To add to the injury you sometimes see trees appearing in the distance and you also see massive texture load almost every time you spawn at a safe house. The water is just okaish. If you swim under water and look up you will see this weird pre-rendered texture of the same waves which looks pretty bad. Think of Crysis (5 years ago) and how that game managed to create unique wave patterns distinct from each other.  One thing that does help is the field of view which can be set at 110 degrees. I honestly thought I was playing on a 2560x1600 monitor.  The physics:  The physics are mostly well done. You can't just keep jumping and climbing everything like in Skyrim. And when you fall down the hill or you don't just hover in air, you slide down and hurt yourself. However, at the same time you can jump and infinite amount of time and run and swim for as long as you want – no stamina whatsoever. The climbing is done pretty well.  The gameplay:  it's Consolized somewhat. For instance if you want to sneak up on someone and knife them you could easily do it without breaking a sweat. For one thing, the enemies' field of vision is extremely limited both during the day and night (if I recall, it was much easier to sneak up on enemies in Far Cry 2 especially after you save enough to buy a stealth suit). You can sneak up on them even when they are supposed to be seeing you and the detection indicator won't even go op. Then, when you are about 10 feet away from them you can click the melee button and knife them easily even if they see you for a second, I kid you not. I forget how many outposts I took out just by using my knife. Also, the menus suck. You go into your loot sack and it's cluttered with stuff you collected. It's not organized in any way in case you want to clear up some room. It would help if the yellow leaves and red leaves were actually pained YELLOW and RED on the screen instead of the game indicating they were through text. Same goes for animal skins. Just color them in appropriately, not too hard.  There's also no more quick save, which works in some linear games with the whole checkpoint system but not here. You HAVE to finish missions before you can manually save (by going to your main menu) or your will lose some progress like crafting and collecting items. Not having the ability to quicksave diminishes the RPG quality of this game in some ways. For instance you go on a mission to shoot 5 deer with a specific weapon. You kill 2 and decide to craft something. Then you fail to kill the other 3 because you miss and run out of bullets. Mission failed. Start over, and craft another item AGAIN. Same goes for loot and collecting hard to reach relics. Also, why only 3 save slots? The two previous games had an unlimited amount of save slots. Why? Why can't I save the best moments of the game?  What they also did is replace the hidden diamond briefcases with boxes of loot that are always shown on your mini-map. Why? Same goes for plants that are to be harvested. That simplifies the game in many ways, so you never really end up searching for something because it's always up there on the minimap. Far Cry 2 didn't have this problem (you didn't have a minimap and you had REALLY look for them diamonds using your proximity tracker). However, at the same time you didn't really collect as much stuff in Far Cry 2 as you do here.  The constant notifications in the upper left corner are also annoying. Seriously, I'm trying to explore that part of the island, I KNOW that going to the Medusa ship is the mission objective, yet I am getting that notification a few times every minute and the only way to make it go away is to complete the actual mission.  The enemy tagging via camera is back from the first game. Only this time, once you tag your enemies you can see them through the terrain! How convenient! Just like in Hitman: Absolution.  The safe houses are still here however, now you can buy and sell your gear at any safe house! Why? You don't need to travel to those very few people who trade your diamonds for weapons and upgrades. Also, you can't sleep at safe houses anymore and pick the time of the day that you want to complete your objective. However, that's hardly relevant now since the day/night cycle now entirely depends on how fast you are moving in the world.  Far Cry 2 healing is back!  The skinning of animals isn't really skinning, it's just taking the same chunk of flesh; be it a turtle, a shark, or a giant carnivorous bird.  You also can't see your legs or cast a shadow…figures.  Viewing any foe or animal through optics automatically tags them, enabling you to see them through walls during firefights, thereby taking out lots of challenge out of the game.  Most animals also take several shots to the head to die. WTF?  The game also features a Kill-Zone type of cover system which is welcome in an FPS.  The AI:  95% of all AI's look alike. Most of them wear red for some reason. Quite often they are as dumb as a stick insofar as taking them out by one goes since most of them probably have extreme cases of near-sightedness. However, when they start ganging up on you and start calling in reinforcements then you got to think quick.  -The weapons:  Pretty decent, the kickback is sometimes not enough though, feels too arcadish. There's some customization there and there, like better scope, extending magazine. The constant lack of ammo forces you to savor your shots. Also, I don't like the way new guns become available to you. Basically new weapons get unlocked when you disable radio towers. How is that relevant to you being able to buy new weapons from your safe house lockers now?  Co-Op is fun but lacks replay value since it's basically a skirmish. In some ways it feels more like a competition rather than a cooperative buddy experience.  Multiplayer is pretty solid, I must say. What's annoying though is constantly getting the temporary killer instinct ability and being able to see through walls for some time. I also like how when the team loses, the best player from the team is granted freedom by the victorious team.   All in all,decent game that sucks you in

Alright, where to begin...  The game is completed, story wise. I would say i haven't enjoyed a game that much for quite some time. Story was great, although would have prefered the villain be done little better. The main villain of the game was little unneccesary. Not complaining, i had fun either way. Vaas was definitely the most well made character in that game by far, they completely nailed it.  This game has a lot of side activities to do, i mostly did story, which was around 20 hours. I did play on the master difficulty, which was even more fun and quite challenging at the same time. I liked moments where i had to think throughout my actions to make sure i succeed.   Animal hunting is also interesting addition to the game, i actually liked hunting animals. The purpose of hunting animals is for the hide you use to craft from additional weapon slots (up to 4) to inventory slots. You can craft medicine, boosters etc by cutting different plants. Also getting better upgrades require better quality hides from animals.  I absolutely loved the driving mechanics in this game. It really feels like driving a real car, with a little extreme aspect added to it. Very responsive steering and accelerating in general, even handbrake was useful. Crashing was quite realistic.  I am not sure about the AI behaviour since i played on the highest difficulty, but from what i experienced- AI is quite active, compared to some games. Even though i used stealth in most cases, they still discovered dead bodies of their comrades and were alerted right away which made it more challenging to do stealth, i liked that a lot too.  Not only crafting, but skills were interesting too. There were basically 3 types of styles you could end up doing- I picked stealth. You can acquire skills by getting XP from stuff you do. When you lvl up you can pick a skill, every skill adds a part to your tattoo on your left hand. I really liked how it transformed into a pretty cool tattoo in the end.  World is quite huge and environment is really gorgeous. I loved gliding over huge mountains and just looking at the nature.   There are also collectables... 4 types i think-> chests, relics, memory cards and lost messages.  There were minor things that bothered me a little. For example quite annoying was when after a cutscene you had to do something and you failed- you had to watch the cutscene all over again. Made me rage few times :D I wish there was an option to skip the cutscene after you've seen it already once.  For now that's all i can remember about the game, still going to do all the side missions and get all the collectables some time in the future.  To sum up i'd say this is best of Far Cry so far(even better than 4). If you want to play it and enjoy the hell out of it, play on the highest difficulty, makes the game last longer ;) Surprisingly works stealth quite well in this game, which is unusual for such straight-forward games. Make sure you know what style you wanna go and make your skill decisions wisely ;)  'For the sake of my friends...or Citra?!' 'Did I ever tell you the definition of Insanity?'   I'd rate the game 9.0/10.0 Screw you cutscene and Hoyt :)

Ah, what to say about this game. You play as Jason Brody and the game takes place on Rook Island. Beyond that there is an adventure of killing, hunting, and occasional drug use.   The basic premise of the game is that you, your friends, your girlfriend and your brothers are all on vacation going around and living it up. Well surprise, surprise when you get kidnapped and taken by local psycho Vaas. The game spans across a large island and smaller sub island in the later part of the game that has you trying to relocate everyone who was taken before they are killed or sold off, and enacting revenge against both Vaas and Hoyt for what they've taken from you. What stands in your way is the feral wildlife and once sane residents of the island. Vaas commands an army of crazies that terrorize the people and you join the Rakyat. The Rakyat are citizens who have had their share of Vaas and fight to have him put down and reclaim their island. A sort of red vs. blue take on it, with animals being the purple team.   The psychedelic drug trips are always interesting. Walking across a walkway of old CRT TV's while seeing things to your sides, hearing voices from the past- it all comes together to throw things into disarray. Interesting imagery and vibrant colours that pop out or draw attention make the sections very enjoyable to look at, and you will be when they limit your walking speed to a crawl, which is something I personally hate in any game, this being no different. Past this brief description I won't say much in regards to this. I feel the little drug trips were something better experienced first hand than anything else.   The game features a FPS and RPG-esque like gameplay style that blends together quite well I feel. You earn the standard EXP that you would expect to see in RPG games, and more so if you dispatch of the enemies with more finesse. Headshots give more, and special kills with the machete earn the most. This EXP is then used to give you skill points which make Jason excel in his island life. With three skills trees to choose from, varying in combat, stealth, and survival aspects, you have some choice in how you want to see your character grow; however, it is possible to get all of the skills in the game before you finish it. I got them all about 65%-70% of the way through, but I personally tried to get as much EXP as possible because it I feel it added to the challenge and fun of the game. Remaining undetected while capturing enemy outposts and chain kills with the machete and the like,so your experience may be completely different.   Rook Island is nothing if not the biggest culmination of hateful animals in gaming history. I've been attacked by more tigers, bears, sharks, alligators, leopards, and stray dogs with rabies than I fired bullets throughout my journey. I've been attacked by more tigers than I have anything else put together. I get the feeling any fear I would have of a tiger in real life is lessened because I have just gotten used to seeing them and then defending myself before they try and maul me. One word of advice I can give is to keep a shotgun handy. The best way to deal with any animal you have to hunt is a shotgun, or a bow but it is not as powerful on animals as it is humans.   The visuals of the game are fantastic. Sprawling landscapes and deep waters, claustrophobic and haunting caverns, and the great outdoors. The graphics for the game are great, it looks fantastic most of the time, odd graphical issues rear themselves every now and then, but the entirety of the visuals is grand. Deep blues for the water, lush green for the vegetation, thick blacks and bright lights to assist the atmosphere, these all combine to give a memorable experience worth taking in when they present themselves, which is common. I often found myself over looking the lands from a radio tower or cliff face and seeing a near awe inspiring world- the sheer number of screenshots that I took of the game offer no less to the game than what I am describing. I would recommend, while playing, to just take a few moments to breathe the game in. It really is something worth looking at when the over-saturation of games with painfully crippled colour palettes have flooded and overflowed our vidya market.   To keep this incoherent and already too long review of going on any further I will wrap it up here. This game is one I highly recommend, especially considering I put in near 40 hours and beat it in less than a week, which is something I don't do at all. The visuals of the game in both the worlds presentation and the mind bending visuals of the drag addled trips through your psyche set my heart fluttering because of my deep love of anything psychological or similar. The gameplay was entertaining, offering a high integrity towards playing how you want, even going as far as covering some outposts with grass that you can then blanket in flames. The sound design, quality, and soundtrack sealed the deal together offering excellent fidelity and mood/theme fitting tracks and ambiance.   Overall, this is a game I highly recommend. Even more so when you take into consideration the game goes under $10 during large sales. What excuse is there to not pick this up and live it?

The game that would not end! Vaas stole the show as the game's initial villain, though, so the twists and turns were worth the price of admission.  I played the first Far Cry twice and promptly uninstalled Far Cry 2 after 30 minutes of getting tired of enemy respawns and fetch quests. This latest sequel is a derivative of both, hoping to glean one-man-army tactical fighting situations from each, yet the story is—often comically—just interesting enough to keep you engaged to see what remote-jungle-island-induced wackiness awaits you next.  In certain parts, it seeks to shock simply for the sake of shocking. Gameplay-wise, it's a combination of the grittiness of Dead Island with the over-the-topness of Borderlands. It's trippy enough to hold your interest, yet disposable enough to make your maniacal killing machine dreams come true.

I know this game has been out for the longest time, but if you're like me, you are just recently contemplating getting it.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes rpg's, adventure games, story driven titles, or any game that makes you feel like an all around badass. Ubisoft should be commended for their ability to tinker with the Far Cry series. While they didn't initially develop the first game, once Crytek signed a deal with EA, Ubisoft could have just left the Far Cry series to rot. Instead, we got a rather interesting sequel with a totally different setting and style of gameplay.  The main problems with Far Cry 2, though, are a lack of meaningful side content, horrible navigation and a rather pointless open-world to explore. While there were moments of beauty and the AI was super deadly, the game ended up being a bit of a drag. It simply wasn't fun for a majority of the campaign, even if it's fleeting moments of entertainment were blissful.  Far Cry 3 took things even further. In adapting a more complex story, the game is immediately more urgent than it's predecessor. While I can't say that all the characters are fully fleshed out human beings, at least having a motivation to explore a jungle island makes sense. The villain is quite a trip.  The island is also more conveniently spaced out. Instead of a vast terrain devoid of life and fuana, almost every area on the 'Rook Islands' contains something to do. Those somethines usually end up being random loot, hidden treasures, animals to hunt for upgrades or outposts to capture for quick travel points.  Quick travel really is what helps move this game along. It may end up being a bit too easy, but not having to trek a quarter mile to get to the next mission is a joy. It keeps to engaged in the story while also opening the possibility to indulge in some of the side missions.  I do have to say that the driving is beyond awful. Far Cry 2 managed to get that one better. The boss battles are also hugely underwhelming. As manic as some of the antagonists can be, finishing them with QTEs is pretty lame.  I also don't know if I enjoy the Radio Tower quests. They are functionally the same as the viewpoints from Assassin's Creed. Ubisoft just loves homogenizing their titles into one super game (which ended up being the deplorable Watch_Dogs). It is cool to see the vistas, but it feels like a missed opportunity to do something more unique.  I also kind of dislike the main player character. Everything in his world seems catered toward a male audience. While that is mostly a personal complaint, I don't see how a female gamer would find anything interesting about this. The 'love interest' (if you can even call her that) is so bland, but she shows a lot of skin, so clearly shes targeted at a male demographic.  I can't really come up with any other complaints. Far Cry 3 is just stellar throughout. It may be a bit on the easy side and have some heavily scripted missions, but it's just super fun. That almost every little distraction provided actually provides bonuses to the player is super great. More games should allow their side missions to be meaningful.  So if you can get past some of the story issues and lack of difficulty, I would recommend this game. It's got a pretty decent length and even has co-op. You will more than likely spend a good deal of time playing it.  8/10

One of the most amazing First person action shooters I've ever played. With amazing graphics, story telling, and gameplay, Farcry 3 is sure to make your mind explode. One of the major strong points of the game is the open world feature. This is prominent in all of the Farcry games, but in Far cry 3, the setting, Rook Island, is by far the best. The map is massive, estimated to be 4-5 square miles. It's full of different wildlife, such as sharks, lions, deer, and lizards. The main biome in the map is jungle, but there is also beaches, mountains, and open plains. Relating to the map, the graphics are fantastic. It is one of the best looking PC games I've seen in awhile. If you see the first screenshot I've posted, the draw distance is very large, and everything looks great at a distance. The character models are also very good. Faces look amazing, and the devs also payed attention to scars, pores, and moles/freckles. The scenery is beautiful, one of the most attracting parts of the game I would have to say. Walking through the forest alone is amazing. It blew my mind. Apart from visuals, the game also does a very good job with gameplay. All throughout the entire game, you had options, going stealthy or going loud and getting into a big fire fight. The guns in the game are also very balanced as well, each one has it's ups and downs. Sliding is also another cool feature in FC3. Sliding can help you quickly dodge bullets or get into cover to escape enemy vision. Apart from all of that, a new feature in FC3, crafting, is also very cool. Hunting animals will get you hide, which you can turn into a bag to create an extra weapon slot, or extra weapon ammo, or tons of other things. This was one of my favorite features in the game by far. The core of the game, storytelling, is the most appealing part of the game. The main character's name is Jason Brody. Him and his friends get trapped on an island known by Rook island, which is controlled by drug lord pirates. The main goal of the game is to rescue all of your friends and kill the main antagonist, Vass. You travel to many different parts of the map in search of them, and meet many new people in the process, such as Citra, who is a leader of a clan/tribe/group. A big part of the story is the dynamic characters. For example, the main character, Jason, undergoes so much throughout the entire story. He starts as one person, and ends up as an entirely different person. It's very entertaining to go through these changes with him. I really got attached to him as a character, and was very sad when the game ended. Speaking of the game ending, the while campaign is long, it took me a week of playing 2-3 hours per day to beat it, and I enjoyed every minute. Another thing I'd like to call out, which isn't very important to the key functions of the game, is the soundtrack. FC3's soundtrack is pure bliss. The music starts playing at the best possible times, and it sounds amazing when it does. The composer/producer, Brian Tyler, did an outstanding job. You can listen to it here:         YouTube™ Video:  Far Cry 3 - Brian Tyler - Soundtrack. Full OST.(Radio&Club)

Whether you want to explore a massive jungle, hunt animals with a variety of weapons, kill bad guys, blow up cars/buildings or set terrain on fire - this is the game for you.  Far Cry 3 continues on the foundation of Far Cry 2 except it's not as punishing in terms of equipment, by which I mean that you don't need to swap your weapon for a new one or repair them after firing them once.   + Ammo isn't too hard to come by. You pick it off fallen enemies or use the cash you scavenge to refill your stock at safehouses.  + To heal you actually need medicine which is acquired by crafting it using green (types of) plants that you collect in the jungle. You don't regenerate all your health (you start out with 2 slots of health) by just standing around, stepping away from the more commonly used auto-heal-regen these days. + The soundtrack is lovely. + Amazing scenery!  - Day/night cycle mechanic based on your movement, both WASD and mouse. You can stand perfectly still (WASD) but still move time forward by wiggling your mouse. - Wonky AI at times. If one enemy detects you they all know where you are even if it's never announced (by a shout/gunfire/etc), even if said enemy only detected you AS you performed the silent takedown. - Platforming (for climbing signal towers among other things) can be tricky. Ledges that can be climbed are marked in a certain way but you can't climb them unless you are given the indicator to climb them. Except that you can if you spam your jump-button, unless it doesn't trigger because you spammed it.  All in all - very much recommended!

I love this game.  I started it Holiday 2012, probably just after Christmas, along with the Steam versions of Max Payne 3 and Dark Souls. Over the next few months, I sunk dozens upon dozens of hours into Dark Souls and more (when you include Wiki time and Xbox 360 horseplay), and horsed around in Max Payne 3, but of the three games I got two years ago, THIS is the one I felt most compelled to finish. (Still haven't -- and I only finished Dark Souls because I could, I was content to just pvp all the time). Alas, life gets in the way and after months of on-and-off play, I didn't really play FC3 again until a week ago.  I am plowing through FC3 now, because on my birthday, my sister got me FC4 for my Xbox One. Before I have yet another addition to my pileup of unfinished/unstarted games, I wanted to give the earlier installment all my attention. All the praise it got in fall 2012 is much deserved.  The story is great, the characters are a little flat but energetic enough to make believe in their fictional lives and personalities. I am given direction and guidance in an open-world game while being encouraged to go my own way. The gunplay and stylistic elements of combat are as good as any great shooter and the depth of the loot just enough to keep me interested in changing it up and getting new gear as I plunder Rook Island.  As for the islands themselves, they are a blast to explore. I never finished the original Far Cry when I played it on my PC about 9 years ago, but I remember that game and Crysis (which was also from Crytek, the original makers of FarCry) having some of the most immersive and interesting envrionments to explore in most of the first-person games I have EVER played (in FarCry I would go crouch/prone somewhere and just spy on the enemy camps, listening to their banter and figuring out ways to mess with them. Because of all the dicking around I'm not really sure how the game started or where it was taking me to, lol. I have a similar case with Borderlands 1 and 2). This game accomplishes the same feat of wonder, danger and personality. The blood of adventure runs through its veins.  My only gripe is that Far Cry 3 reuses too many assets (NPC voices, filler dialogue, etc.) and that the enemy groups don't adapt to you so much as you makeing them dance like puppets. The multiplayer has some balance/depth issues as well but it works for what it is, and is fun and fast while being tactical to a degree.  For the record, I've never finished a Bethesda game either, so Far Cry 3 will get special honours as the first open-world immersive experience I've finished in the current modern era of gaming. Kudos, Ubisoft.  Going back to my speel in the beginning of this review, yes, I will drop FarCry 3 for a while, but I intend to keep playing this in the years to come. Rook Island is my hunting ground, and I want to hunt.  9/10 -- the game is timeless. Could've rated it higher if it had more juice to the inventory/loot and the NPC AI behaviour and assets, and the sidequests.

Rich story, great villains, fun side missions, huge open world, upgrade your character and weapons as you progress, characters you get attached to, and a humbling emotional ending. $20 Was a no brainer, would have bought this game full price.  9.5/10

I bought Far Cry 3 during one of the -80% sales. It's not that I wasn't excited, I had seen Vaas in previews and that was intriguing enough. I also remembered Far Cry 2 fondly. It's just that I was a little bored with big budget shooters.  My first impression of the game was that it was predictable, shallow, and cliche, but that the gameplay itself was pretty fun. The RPG aspects were cool, I liked planning ahead in the skill trees, deciding what kind of fighter I wanted to be. Overall it just seemed like a big shooter playground. Blow things up, shoot a lot of people, leave c4 on roads and blow up a passing jeep full of pirates, etc. I played the game casually for quite awhile, just opening it up to have a little fun before I had to go to work. However by the time I finished the game I felt differently.  The gist of the story is that you're a rich white male in his 20's, who goes vacationing in the islands. Pirates capture you and your friends, and now it's up to you to save them all. The natives of the island are trying to war against the pirates, but they need a magical white man to save them, because they're just brown savages etc. Typical Pocahontas/Avatar thing. However, the deeper I got into the story, I began to notice little hints and motiffs (recurring themes). There was something going on between the lines in the writing...  Jason, your character, starts off as a frightened normal person who is horrified to have to kill someone. Once he gets better at it, and realizes how good he is at it, he starts to actually have fun. At one point, Jason has a conversation with one of the friends he had saved, and asks her what it felt like to win a race (shes a swimmer). He tells her at first killing was scary, but now it just 'feels like winning'. His friends start looking at him a little strangely as he becomes more and more ruthless, getting deeply involved with the natives who gradually tattoo his arm with tribal markings.   As you get further along, it becomes clear that you aren't the white man saving those silly brown savages, you're just being used. Jason, however, begins to see himself as the hero of the native people. Gradually, his motives shift from rescuing his friends to fighting this war.   At one point, he could escape with all his friends and go back to his old life, but chooses to stay on the island and continue fighting--and not for noble reasons.    This all mirrors your experience as the player (likely a young white male, statistically). As you have fun wiping out pirate camps in all sorts of creative ways, Jason's friends worry that he's starting to have fun killing people. The natives hailing you as their hero mirrors the typical game or hollywood movie story, when actually they're just using you, a gung-ho insane white person, as a tool in their civil war.  I can't possibly cover all the metaphors and comparisons, but here's some rapid-fire ones: Vaas is particularly interesting as a sort of mirror figure to Jason, or a glimpse at what Jason could become. The use of psychedelic drugs to help portray Jason getting deeper and deeper into the rabbit hole--oh and the use of Alice In Wonderland quotes. Jason's relationship with the beautiful native woman who loves him unconditionally because he's the best at killing, a gamer fantasy.  As the end of the story plays out, the metaphors gets more in-your-face. There's a choice you the player has to make at the very end. Stop reading here if you don't want it spoiled.    You're looking into the eyes and listening to the pleas of what seems like a real person, a young woman who loves you, a realistic, fleshed out character with flaws, feelings, and normal relationship problems. Then you have to choose: 1) Save your friends and go back to the real world, possibly with an imperfect, complicated, realistic relationship with your old girlfriend. or 2) Cut her throat while she begs and pleads, and join Citra, the beautiful, busty, half-naked woman who fell in love with how well you kill people and is entirely subservant to you, staying on the island as the best warrior.  No matter how many hundreds of pirates I had fun killing with machetes, rocket launchers, flying jeeps, and angry tigers, I would never click to cut her throat, not even just to see the other ending. It's one thing to play a typical shooter game, blasting faceless nameless enemies by the hundreds, or killing truly evil villains, but it's something else entirely to kill a helpless character that feels like a real person--and I think that was the point.    Rating: A-

'Far Cry 3' is a very enjoyable open-world sandbox first-person shooter. Right off the bat, I was free to explore one of the two islands. I spent the first 16 hours of the game exploring, activating radio towers (the only time to date I actually enjoyed first-person platforming), hunting animals and relics, crafting bigger wallets and ammo bags, and -- the best part of the game -- liberating outposts. Given the dynamic game environment, each of my encounter or scenarios with enemies varied, and this made 'Far Cry 3' unpredictable and replayable.  It wasn't until my 24th hour that I moved on with the story missions, which feature exciting set pieces and action. Just when I thought I've got the rhythm of the game down, the game granted me access to the second island. This second island features a different terrain, providing new challenges in liberating outposts and making me rethink my tactics. It's also full of nooks and cranies and secrets waiting to be discovered, just like on the first island.  One of my very few gripes about 'Far Cry 3', however, was the boss battles. Like some of the contemporary action games I've played, boss battles were reduced to quick time events. This diminished the tension of the conflicts and made me feel more like an observer, resulting in rather unsatisfying gameplay. One particular boss battle was particularly disappointing because his character was already under developed; battling him by pressing a few buttons on cue made the experience even more underwhelming. This made me miss grand boss battles like those found in games like 'Crysis'  Despite my annoyance about boss battles, 'Far Cry 3' remained entertaining and fresh as I approached my 50th hour into the game. The game has surprisingly much to offer. 'Far Cry 3' gets a very enthusiastic thumbs-up from me.

You can spend dozens of hours just exploring the Rakyat Islands and find cool stuff and doing side quests, hang glide across the ocean, or go knee deep into the storyline, which is what I suggest doing. Far Cry 3 does an excellent job of blending realistic and (occasionally) silly elements (you'll be fighting a human trafficking ring by...burning down their weed  production...yeah?)  but never feels forced or boring to play. gunplay is as fast and fluid as you want it to be, and the excellent branching skill tree system gives you multiple ways to play and approach the game. Everything oozes replayability and action in a well done package. My only real complaint is that the last 1/3 of the story doesn't feel like it transitioned smoothly. Vaas Montenegro is an expertly done villain (he's on the bloody game art for christ's sake) yet he's not even the main antagonist (some dutch a**hole named Hoyt is), and I don't really agree with it.  Despite the small flaws and the requirement to use Uplay (you will need to use it for this), the game is excellent and one I can heartily recommend. Farcry 3 is an open-world RPG shooter; and one of the best shooters I've played so far. This game inclines more to a shooter while attempting to balance it's RPG-play. The RPG aspect comes from the customisability of the player's loadout (weapon etc), allowing for the player to take on an objective with his most comfortable style. Although Farcry 3 has a skill tree or 'perk' tree that introduces more role-playing elements, the fact that every skill in there can be obtained diminishes the 'different player, different stats' element of a RPG. Hence, the game feels more inclined towards a First-person shooter. The unique thing about this game is the integration of animals into the gameplay. This gives the game a more realistic feel as animals are abound in the wild and they can come as a boon or a bane to anyone. Farcry 3 has effectively brought out this aspect by having animals roam the wild and aiding you while you set up a raid on an enemy camp or create confusion for the player while attempting to raid an enemy camp. Animals in captivity can be used to your advantage against its captors, or while sneaking up from the flanks of an enemy group/convoy/camp, a wild animal attacks you causing your plan to fail. The introduction of wildlife into game also allows for side 'quests' such as hunting and also crafting of personal equipment. This aspect gives the game a more varied feel as opposed to traditional FPS. On the topic of realism, as with many other games, the producers have created the protaganist (the player) as an android running on nuclear power. This could have been improved with the need for sleep (such as a timer which resets upon sleep or penalises players with reduced stats/abilities/actions); that, however, is my own take on how the game could have been made more realistic and may not suit all players out there. The graphics of the game is comparable to most FPS games out there on the market (2012). Although not top notch for the year, in my opinion, it is very good considering it is an open world game and has many aspects fused into its gameplay. The actions and shootouts of the game is highly non-linear due to its open world setting. It allows one to play a First-person shooter the likes of Modern Warfare/Black Ops without having a linear flow. This aspect, in my opinion, gives the player a more 'on-the-set' feel; where every action that the player makes, leads to something totally different in the reaction of the enemies. I personally went for the long range and stealthy approach, thinning the enemy ranks with hidden sniper fire and then going in 'Black Ops' style when the time is right. Other players can choose to go in loud, taking out groups of enemies with RPG or Grenades then finishing the rest with heavy fire. This myriad of interchangeable play style, which differs from player to player, is the game's main plus point - one which will make Farcry 3 suit the many gamers out there. In all, it is fair to say that this game is a strong contender for the title of FPS or Action/Adventure Game of the Year. It has a heavy FPS aspect while giving the player a role-playing 'feel'. It is definitely a must-try game for those die-hard FPS fans who want to experience something different from the linear FPS games. - 9.1/10

This game is without a doubt the best one I've ever played.   The graphics are absolutely stunning. This game gives you the ability to conquer camps and missions how YOU want to do it. An awesome exp. and ranking system that lets you pick from a tree of upgrades that is filled with helpful benefits lets you build your character stronger and more lethal as you progress through the game. Craftable items requiring materials gathered from skinning the wild animals you find in the jungles or plants that you cut down let you grow your arsenal of items bigger and better, very similar to the way you grow the physical abilities of your character as the story progresses, and all this is done at an achievable yet challenging pace. You're constantly able to upgrade your character and his items as you go through the game.  Personally, I was never left bored in this game. Between the hunting tasks, the infiltration of the pirate encampments, and the main story missions, there was always gripping content to play through and it left me with feeling of satisfaction everytime I completed any of the tasks. Like I've said before, this game has a way of being the perfect balance of fun and challenging.   Don't know how else to put it: This game is absolutely incredible, and you cannot possibly go wrong adding it to your library. 10/10

You can read any number of other reviews that are going to discuss gameplay, and the story, and the crafting system, and all other aspects of this game. I've got what comes down to one very simple reason for loving this game, and that's the towers. Spread through Rook Island are eighteen radio towers. Each time you climb a tower you unlock the map of the surrounding area and get some free weapons and such. So, what is it about the towers that makes FC3 such a joy? Although identical in structure, each tower has been damaged to some degree, making each tower a unique mini puzzle, figuring out where you have to jump and climb to get to the top. It would have been so simple to make each climb identical, just a simple cookie-cutter pattern, and 99 games out of 100 would have done just that. FC3 went that extra mile, put in that added touch. That's what makes this such a great game. They thought about it, thought about what we'd like, what they'd like as gamers, and implemented it. I don't say this often, but good going on this one, Ubisoft.

Far Cry 3 is a messy game. It has highs and lows.   The best part of the game is when it lets you play. The hunting, bounty hunting, and post liberating missions are rewarding and exciting, even for the second or third playthrough. The rakyat challenges are great fun too!  Exploration elements, like collecting boxes and statues are okay, if you are into that thing, but they feel rather useless timewasters, every cave looks the same, there are no real hidden beauties worth exploring for, and the boxes usually contain pocketmoney you won't need anyway.  The main mission line is great, until the second act starts, and until its your first go. The unskippable cutscenes are extremely frustrating, and the second half (or rather, quarter?) feels lazy. The story serves the game to a degree, but you have to let logic go. Its a drug filled powerfantasy after all, nothing is really true, is it?  The gunplay is solid, leveling up Brody feels rewarding, you really feel progress and some skills elevate the gameplay for sure. Crafting is mediocre at best, its really just a grind, but at least it gives you reason to hunt.   The great thing is that the game opens up relatively quickly (after ~15 mins of forced hand holding), and you can pretty much unlock all the crafted items, except some special ones, and level up the character fairly, except some things which are gated with story related missions.  Being said that, the game is full of performance issues, and most of them are only occuring in this retail version. First of all, the double DRM is a joke. It has no use, since the multiplayer is _unplayable_. I couldn't find a simple PvP match, there were simply not enough people playing the game, and Co-op is unplayable too, its riddled with game breaking bugs, and very common lag spikes.  So, buying the game solely for the purpose of testing multiplayer options was a bad choice for me. But little did I know, that I won't be able to enjoy the game on higher graphics settings neither. The single player part outright crashes whenever I turn textures higher than the lowest setting.   This is an issue for many, and it occurs on every driver version and both on ATI and NVIDIA cards. Some wrote it happens only in the opening cutscene, for me it kills the game whenever I want to use the camera. It might be some texture streaming issue on the camera and the phone in the opening cutscene.  Second thing is that the game performance slopes down, after 10-20 minutes of gameplay, the framerate sinks and stays low for no apparent reason.  The thing is, that the >cracked< version of the game has none of these issues, even on highest DX9 settings. Oh sure, there is no multiplayer, but thats _not even working in the retail version neither_.  Summary: - great visuals (if your version lets you use them) - solid gunplay - passable single player story missions - great side missions  - game breaking bugs - multiplayer is not working - stupid, useless Uplay integration
The game has an amazing gameplay and a good story. If you buy it for the multiplayer don't because the multiplayer is dead.

The best way I can sum up Far Cry 3 is Skyrim, but with guns. Well okay, it's not quite as deep, with only a basic crafting system and a single layer of plot, but what Far Cry lacks in depth it makes up more than enough with its fast action, dynamic missions, and luscious graphics.  Set on a chain of islands in somewhere in the south Pacific ocean, Far Cry places you in the shoes of a thrill-seeking vacationer who must rise to the challenge of rescuing his friends and overcoming the local drug smugglers embedded in the area. You've got an ever-growing arsenal of weapons, whatever vehicle you can jump inside of, and a variety of items to upgrade as you wage war across the islands. The views are beautiful and the locals (and wildlife) are deadly.  The sense of scale in Far Cry 3 is incredible. Virtually every part of the landscape you can see -and there's a lot of it - is somewhere you can go. Cars, boats, hangliders and more are scattered throughout, and there are pockets of enemies and roaming packs of animals waiting for you everywhere.  The real targets, aside from the game's primary mission, are the small bases where enemies conduct business, and each is different in its design and position in the landscape. You can run in guns blazing or sneak through, sabotaging traps and disabling enemies one at a time - it's up to you.  I enjoyed the story of Far Cry 3, which is slightly predictable, but still has its share of twists. My favorite part of the game was exploring the islands and taking out the enemy bases.  Normally with this type of game, I get tired of the tedium and eventually quit, but this wasn't the case with Far Cry 3 - I stuck it out and finished it, and was sad when it was over. With a ton of hidden locations and hard-to-find collectibles though, it's easy to find more to do.  My only complaint about Far Cry 3 is that it requires uPlay to be installed and started up when launched. I'd prefer that games I buy through Steam only have one launcher. But that's just me.

The uplay wasn't a problem for me :)  Story: Jason Brody, his older and younger brothers Grant and Riley, his girlfriend Liza, and their friends Daisy, Keith, and Oliver, vacation in Bangkok to celebrate Riley getting his pilot's license. While skydiving, they land on an archipelago named the Rook Islands, controlled by pirates under the control of Vaas. Grant and Jason are held and taunted by Vaas while the others are taken to be held for ransom. Grant engineers their escape but is killed by Vaas, and Jason manages to scramble away. He is met by Dennis Rogers, a native of island working with the Rakyat tribe to seize control back from the pirates. Dennis sees the potential in Jason to follow the Rakyat 'path of the warrior' in rescuing his friends, and gives him a tatau that gives Jason the strength and knowledge to defeat the pirates. With Dennis's help, Jason locates Daisy and takes her to the house of Dr. Earnhardt, who offers to shelter Jason's other friends from Vaas. Dennis introduces Jason to Citra, the leader of the Rakyat and Vaas' sister, who tells Jason she will offer her help if he can retrieve the Silver Dragon, a ceremonial knife revered by the Rakyat. Jason experiences a drug-induced vision given to him by Citra to identity Willis Huntley, a CIA agent operating on the island with information on both his friends and the knife. Willis has been monitoring Hoyt Volker, a deranged South African slave trader who Vaas has been working with, selling those he captures into human slavery even after the ransoms have been paid, and who is also engaged in drug trafficking from the island. Keith has already been sold to Bambi 'Buck' Hughes, who offers to give Keith back to Jason in exchange for finding the Silver Dragon, buried in ancient Chinese temples on the island. Jason eventually finds the knife, but when Buck reneges on the deal, Jason kills him with it. Jason brings Liza, Keith and Oliver to Dr. Earnheart's, where they find a boat needing minor repairs to be able to escape the island. When Keith reveals that he saw Riley shot and killed, the others try to convince Jason to leave with them, but Jason, now set on the path of the warrior, vows revenge on Vaas and Hoyt, worrying Liza. Jason brings the knife to Citra, and he is revered as a hero of the Rakyat. With her help, Jason infiltrates Vaas' compound and kills him. Willis, who has been given orders to leave the island, provides Jason with transport to Hoyt's island and information on Sam Becker, another CIA operative that has gained the trust of Hoyt and is working deep undercover in Hoyt's army of privateers. Sam helps Jason to similarly gain Hoyt's trust by identifying a potential assassination attempt on Hoyt by the remnants of Vaas' pirates. Hoyt offers Jason the ability to interrogate a prisoner which turns out to be Riley. Jason, with Sam's help, is able to discrete reveal himself while still feigning his support for Hoyt by beating up Riley to get his name. Hoyt is pleased with the results, and offers Jason and Sam to a come to a private poker game. Jason and Sam arrange to kill Hoyt and rescue Riley at the game, but first assure that Hoyt's men cannot respond quickly enough by destroying their fuel depot and communication network. At the game, Hoyt suddenly kills Sam and slices off Jason's finger, having figured out the deception, but Jason gains the advantage and kills Hoyt in a knife fight. Hoyt's dying words reveal that Riley is about to be flown off the island, and Jason races to stop this. He frees Riley, and Riley takes control of one of Hoyt's helicopters to make their escape. They return to Dr. Earnheart's, finding the building aflame and the man dying after an attack by the Rakyat, who took their friends. They fly to the Citra's temple, where Cirta forces Jason of making a choice to complete his path of the warrior by killing his friends and allowing her to be his mate, or to abandon it by letting them go and return to the life he knew. The player's decision affects the game's outcome. If the player should opt to complete the path, Jason kills his friends to Citra's praise, and then he and Citra copulate; after this, Citra then kills Jason, and as he dies, she tells him that he died like that of a warrior, assuring that his child she now carries will become the new Rakyat leader. If the player opts to save the friends, Dennis is outraged that Jason refused to accept Citra's love, and rushes to stab him, but Citra moves in the way and takes the blade herself. As Jason and his friends flee the template, Dennis is remorseful at having killed Citra. The friends are then seen leaving the island on the boat, with a voiceover by Jason knowing that it will be impossible to fully recover from his ordeal.  GAMEPLAY: Far Cry 3 is a first-person shooter, which also features role-playing game elements including experience points, skill trees, and a crafting system. The player has the ability to take cover behind objects to break enemies' lines of sight and to peek around and over cover and blindfire. The player has the ability to perform silent takedowns by performing melee attacks from above, below, or close behind. The game's narrative director, Jason Vandenberghe, said that the story mode map is around ten times larger than the game's previous installments. Players are given the ability to survey and plan out their attacks with stealth takedown combinations and tag enemies with the camera in order to track their movement once they break the player's line of sight.[8] Equipment is controlled by a simple system. As missions are completed, new items are unlocked to be purchased or crafted by Jason, using the pelts of various animals found around the island to improve items-, weapons- and ammunitions-carrying capabilities. When scramblers on radio towers are removed, areas of the map are opened and weapons in the shop are first made available for buying, and ultimately made free. Apart from the basic model of each category which can be picked up from slain enemies or at the start of several missions, most weapons can be upgraded with one or more additions : silencers, larger magazines, better sights are the most common improvements. A special group of weapons (one per category), unlocked depending on achievements, possess maxed out category statistics and/or unique abilities. All weapons are based off existing weapons, using most or all of their official designation, and comes with a description describing their main advantages and inconveniences. Weapon comparison can be made depending on 5 statistics : accuracy, damage (per round), range, rate of fire, and mobility (the better the mobility, the faster the character can move while firing). Apart from guns, the player also has access to a few unique weapons or tools. Ammunitions for each weapon category can be picked up or, in the case of arrows, retrieved after use. Reloading and magazine swap speeds vary from weapon to weapon. Reloading takes place automatically when the weapon runs empty, or can be triggered manually. For the bow, arrow nocking and pulling takes time before shooting, and conditions the arrow's arch, precision and power : the longer, the better. Area effect arrows can eventually be crafted. As outposts of Vaas' pirate group are attacked and retaken, the vicinity around the outpost becomes safer, it unlocks new side quests for that area, involving missions like hunting the many different wildlife species on the island to upgrade ones equipment.[9] Skills are collected by gaining experience from completing missions and killing enemies, and are unlocked in three skill trees, which correspond to the Spider, the Heron, and the Shark. Each skill tree upgrades different aspects of Jason's abilities, with the Spider upgrading his stealth takedowns and hunting skills, Shark for assault takedowns and health, with the Heron upgrading his long-range takedowns and mobility. When I first heard about this game the initial one-liner stood out - Skyrim with guns. It seemed like every semi-sandboxy FPS game was being hailed as that. Yet, over time it really is quite true. The amount of exploration and depth is quite amazing. The storyline is quite good as well. But that's just my initial, 200 character or less impression.  Mechanics: The mechanics are prett smooth. The UI, as well as the gun UI and the menu system is quite fluid and can be mastered fairly easily. One issue I have with the gun UI is that there are 8 different options and it's easy to select the wrong item/weapon. What's worse is that your switch weapon key, or 'Y' if you use a 360 controller, only switches out between the last 2 weapons. So if you selected C4 on accident then you now have a sniper rifle then C4. Frustrating during hectic moments. Yet, when discussing with friends, by the time you unlock the extra holsters (gun slots) you should've, at least theoretically, mastered the UI. The driving is pretty good, you can certainly tell the difference between each of the vehicles you drive - be prepared to just run past a couple of them saying 'f that noise'. The wingsuit and paragliding? Once you get the mechanics down, awesome fun.  Graphics/Audio: Great! I'm rocking an AMD setup with a 9790 3gb. No hiccups whatsoever. I do have a buddy that has an 7850 1gb, and there's some hiccups when there's some battles going down in open terrain. The view distance + explosions + everything else does tend to drop the framerate below 15 at times. (running a 1080p) Still, it's a visually stunning game with some very good charatcer portrails. THe audio is fantastic - great ambiance from wildlife roaming around to the creaking of radio towers as you climb.  Story: Excellent. Very well-written. It can draw out at times, while at others tend to leave you wanting a little more. However, the storyline is so convoluted that if you put it down for a month, you'd have forgotten what's happening in the Far Cry Universe.   Multiplayer/Co-op: Multiplayer is pretty standard, but nothing to write home about. It's certainly not it's selling point. The co-op is quite fun, but not really a lasting appeal. I play a lot of BF4 so just a disclaimer, I have some pretty big FPS bias - good and bad.  Overall: I give this game a 9/10. It's solid FPS with a great sandbox feel. The storyline is pretty linear, but not so much that you have to feel like you're screwing things up by adventuring around hunting Vaas' & Hoyt's men or just going big game hunting in the caves. For completionist, you'll get 75+ hours out of the game. Fantastic dollar per hour value. I highly recommend it.

In Far Cry 3, you can hunt leopards with flamethrowers. You can jump off of a cliff, glide over an enemy base with your wingsuit, and drop a hundred feet onto a bomb-suited machinegun-wielding badass and break your fall perfectly by running him through the skull with your machete. You can silently pick off enemies from a hundred yards away with your silent rifle, watching with maddened glee as your enemies scramble in all the wrong directions, looking for their hunter like confused prey. You can unleash mountains of lead into legions of enemies with your fully automatic tiger-striped death-dealing bullet hose, laughing with derision as you swallow up enemy bullets with every health syringe you inject. You can destroy a helicopter with a flare gun. It is truly a thing of beauty.  The narrative of the campaign is weak and the characters are even weaker. The campaign will be hit or miss for most people, the individual missions even more so, but outside of the main story you have ultimate freedom to rule this island, YOUR island, however you choose to do so.  Sadly, one of the greatest faults is that the progression of the game is directly linked to the lackluster campaign. Many skills and even an entire southern island will be locked until you trudge through many of the game's missions.  The game has amazing longetivity and replay value. A Study in Missed Opportunity, Plagued By Bizarre Design Choices  First, let me start out by saying that FarCry 3 is a fun game. It's a very cool, original concept that's well-implemented, and right from the very first scene, it's filled with heart-pounding action that does a very good job of making you feel like a normal guy thrown into an extraordinary situation. It's a sandbox-style game, with an absolutely enormous map that's gorgeously rendered, thoughtfully designed, and a lot of fun to explore.  But there are a few design choices that are just absolutely baffling, and really inexcusable in a PC game from a major, experienced developer that's been around for well over a decade.  For example, there is only one volume slider in the audio menu. You can turn the music on or off, and subtitles on or off, that's it. Why!? In every game I ever play, I adjust dialog volumes up a little, and sound effects and music down a bit (actually this is default in most games), so I can clearly hear the dialog. This isn't a 'cheat', it just makes it so I can hear what's being said no matter what else is going on. In Far Cry 3 on the other hand, there have been times when an important phone conversation has been completely drowned out by a combination of music and a thunderstorm. Just bizarre.  Also for some reason, you can't use both mouse and keyboard, and controller, at the same time. Enabling one completely disables the other. The controller setup is reasonably well-implemented, but there are times I really wish I could use the mouse to aim for more precision.  A smaller gripe is that if you alt-tab out of this game, it reverts to Windowed mode, so each time you do so, you have to go back into the menus and turn it back to full-screen. This by itself wouldn't be a bizarre choice, except that if you're playing on controller (which you pretty much have to -- vehicles are completely uncontrollable by keyboard), your mouse is still disabled any time it goes over the game screen (which by default fills the entire window).  Now, let's talk about missed opportunities...  This is a sandbox shooter with as much land mass area as any Bethesda game, and with a story that's deep enough to make it compare favorably with RPGs, despite the fact that the player doesn't really have any choices other than when to advance the main plot. Because of its depth, and the level of immersion it almost manages to achieve, I can't help but wonder why certain features weren't implemented, even optionally, that would complete the immersion.  For example, throughout the game, you hunt and kill an amazing variety of wildlife, all of which is very well implemented, with a living biome that feels very real. Tigers hunt prey animals, prey animals run from predators, and the resulting chases soon blend the spawns into a very pleasingly realistic and diverse biosphere. There are camps dotting the islands, with campfires in most of them and beds in all of them. There is already a crafting system built into the game. It's the -perfect- opportunity to introduce basic survival simulation, like hunger and thirst and the need for sleep.  It would make hunting an even more central part of the game, as you'd have to hunt to survive. It would also be more pleasing to me, to actually utilize the animals I kill. Instead, just like the rich prick the main character started out as, he kills them for their skins, to craft pouches and slings and holsters, nothing more. Why would they not also have him take the meat? They even have stores all over the islands with signs begging for meat, offering money for meat, even listing prices paid for various types of game animals. Even if they couldn't afford the extra development costs to implement a basic needs system like in Fallout: New Vegas, it would have taken almost no extra effort to just add the animal's meat to your rucksack in addition to its skin, so you could at least sell it for other people to eat, instead of slaughtering every animal you see just for its fur in a morally troublesome manner.  Also, there was a great opportunity for character development, that I feel was almost entirely missed. Jason Brody starts out as a whiny, entitled, self-important little brat, living off of daddy's money as he vacations in an exotic locale with his friends. After weeks basically alone, fending for himself in a dangerous tropical archipelago, hunting down pirates, learning advanced combat and stealth techniques and guerilla tactics, and getting himself entangled in a complex struggle between pirates and the native Rakyat tribe, the Jason Brody I play most of the time is a badass. He's self-sufficient, he shows no fear, he carefully crafts battle plans to take out entire outposts of well-armed enemies without even being detected. If he is detected, he keeps his cool and uses hit and run tactics to whittle the enemy forces down one man at a time, until he's victorious. He's like a Navy SEAL on crack.  And then he speaks....  And he's the sams god-forsaken whiny little self-entitled brat, making the same completely idiotic choices time after time after time... (how many times does he have to shout at the top of his lungs while sneaking into an enemy stronghold, so his friends, after week of captivity, won't have to go twenty more seconds without realizing they're being rescued, before he realizes that's NOT A GOOD IDEA!?) In short, the silent killer I play 95% of the time has developed from a kid who barely knows which end of the gun to point at the enemy to a total badass. They do a -great- job of communicating his inexperience and helplessness at the start of the game, and the progression from that to uber-badass feels smooth and intuitive. But the character the developers wrote and voice-acted remains unchanged, completely static and basically unaffected and unenlightened by his experiences as a guerilla warrior.  There are other issues with this game, a huge number if missed opportunities, and a lot of points where it's clear there just is a lack of attention to detail (one skill for example, lets you move at full speed while crouched. Your perspective and your held weapon jostle and move rapidly, as if you're doing just what the skill says: Jungle Run. But they forgot to change the foley! Your footsteps remain the same slow, measured pace they always were when sneaking. I mean... was someone in the audio department asleep that day?)  All of that being said, if you're willing to put up with a lot of annoyances, it's still a fun game, and worth playing. I wouldn't have taken the time to write this, and I wouldn't be so disappointed in its shortcomings, if there weren't a fantastic game lurking behind its issues. In the end analysis, I do recommend this game, but cautiously. If you're a member of its target audience, grab it if you already haven't. If you're the kind of gamer who plays Hardcore New Vegas on the other hand, a roleplayer looking for true, total immersion? It could do a lot better.  And seriously Ubisoft... the gaming industry in general figured out that more player choice in terms of volume controls and control configurations is better in like... 1993. Get your act together, guys!

Book your ticket to enjoy the tropical islands and sightseeing tourism of the 'uninhabited' Rook Island. Enjoy skydiving, hunting, swimming, exploring, and being kidnapped by a slave trader and his band of pirates.  FarCry 3 was an amazing open-world FPS that kept you playing to learn the outcome of Jason Brody and his friends and family. The scenery gives you the sense of a tropical island paradise where you can just lay back and forget everything, but the pirates chasing after you and the inner conflict brings you back and shows you the real story of the island.  The story kept you hanging on and eventually letting you determine the fate of you and your friends. The drug trips remind me of Fallout 3's Point Lookout DLC, hallucinations and drug use is all a part of living on the island. And at points, the ending to the hallucinations left you wondering what really went on. It adds to an already amazing story. And in the end, you get to decide what happens. Not to Vass or Hoyt, but to your friends and yourself.  Combat is seamless and taking cover is as easy as crouching, using the aim button to lean over cover. I had played Deus Ex: Human Revolution right before I picked this game up, and unlike Deus Ex, enemies are not impossible to kill, with just a few bullets to the chest. Flame adds a whole other aspect of gunplay. Burning shrubery, grass, and trees can siphon enemies out of hiding spots, as well as block off escape routes.  As I had just finished Deus Ex, I was still in a cautious stealth gameplay mode, and Far Cry 3 did a good job at the aspect as well. By the end of teh game you're able to take out an entire outpost in just a few seconds all the while staying in stealth. Throwing knives from one enemy unit to the other or taking the pistol off of one person and using it to take out the rest of the outpost. Even taking enemies out from above or below silently, adds to the stealth aspect of the game. It's not the most perfected stealth, but it works for the game's purposes.  I didn't really find too many cons to the game. No game-breaking bugs or easily looked over mistakes. I outright had a great time playing this game and nothing broke it. But, there's always people who will have a different opinion.

Story  In Far Cry 3 you play as Jason Brody, a kind of a spoiled brat who, along with his friends are vacationning on Rook islands somewhere in the Pacific. Things take a turn for the worst when the whole gang is kidnaped by pirates and are held as ransom. You manage to escape, and from there the adventure will include tattoos, hunting, saving your friends, reconquering the island from the pirates and ascend the ranks of the local Maori tribe.  The story is paper thin. FC3 doesn't make the case for first person narratives. After countless pirate kills Brody was still disgusted by skinning an animal or felt horrified by something he kinda did dozens of times before. This wasn't enough to disconnect from the game but it definitely was enough to establish a distance and render to nil any emotionnal involvement.  On the flip side though, the game introduce Vaas, the main antagonist, and he is awesomely written and acted. I would've loved to see him fully developped but alas it wasn't the case. Boy, talk about missed opportunity.   Gameplay  -FC3 has RPG elements, you gain experience from completing main and secondary missions, liberating outposts, finding lost artifacts and so on. The skill tree is divided into three categories that improves hunting, combat, health and survival.  -You have various vehicule at your disposal to get you around. They all handle pretty much the same way except for land vehicules which had a rough edge I liked. Being Far Cry you can also hop onto a glider and there are also ziplines that brings speed to the gameplay.  -I found the main missions to be a lot of fun, they are intense and varied. The same can't be said for optionnal ones. Ranging from menial to plain dull, ythey can all be skipped without generating any meaningful impact on your playthrough. -There are also diversions such as races, hunting and assassination, but they are not that thrilling at all.  -In order to get around you have to be able to see the map and you can do so by activating radio towers scattered across the map. Once you do, a portion of the map will be visible and unlock more missions and diversions. The pirates have many outpost and liberating them will lessened their foothold and open the territory to friendlies and civilian alike.   Combat  Combat is fast and fun. You have many type of weapons available, each containing several weapons. There are also unique weapons that can be earned by completing missions, discovering items or simply advancing through the game.  Though not explicitely said stealth play is THE way to go. For instance liberating an outpost undetected grants you three times the experience points and takedowns are part of the core mechanics of the game.  Takedown are quasi quick time events that lets you insta-kill an enemy. Simply approach one undetected, push the prompt button and watch. The basic takedown is a stab but skill points can let you buy several other type of takedowns such as from below, from above and the ability to chain them.  The basic takedown is savage and thrilling and offer an additionnal strategic option to combat, but I can't help but feeling that this mechanic would've been right at home in a 3rd person action game but feels clunky in a FPS. Returning from FC2, wildfire play an important part in the game. It can cutoff enemies, set them on fire but can turn on you in a pinch.   Wildlife and crafting  Wild and plant life plays a HUGE role in FC3, you can hunt the former and gather the latter. Upon progressing in the game you will unlock recipes. They can be crafted with the proper amount of plant samples and will grant you temporary effects.  You can also hunt the wildlife to gather their hide. These will upgrade your equipment so that you can carry more weapons and ammo and a bigger inventory. Wildlife is quite diverse as there are boars, antilopes, tigers and pack of wild dogs just to name a few.  If there is one aspect the Ubisoft nailed it is this one. Not only does wildlife adds realism to the setting but also makes it completely alive and unpredictable. One of the nicest moments in my playthrough was when I was slowly approaching an outpost, then in walks a tiger who proceded to maul all pirates in the camp and liberating it in the process!    Difficulty, money and others  Here comes the negative stuff. Actually it can all be summed up in two words : hand holding.  I set my game to hard expecting a challenge. The hard setting in FC3 is the equivalent of easy or normal in most other games, depending on how hardcore of a gamer you are. Let me put it this way, my health is gone and getting another bullet doesn't kill me.  Next there is money. Very soon in the game you will be chin-deep in money, it is everywhere. Most actions that you do lets you earn money on top of finding it all over the place. If a torrent of money wasn't enough as you activate radio towers the merchants will give you their weapons for free! Needless to say that the economy in FC3 is quite underwhelming.  I mentionned loot, but there is no item system in FC3, the myriad of items found totally meaningless except to be sold in the store. Too bad as it could have become the basis for some barter system that would have been interesting.  Hunting and crafting is amazing but by the 1/5 of my playthrough I had all the upgrades I could have and there is no other incentive for hunting except maybe to sell hides. As for crafting, well, you can't walk ten steps without stumbling on a plant. They appear on the minimap and shimmer in your field of view, just in case you missed it.  Here you are, in this big sandbox game and exploration is neither encouraged nor rewarded. Looking for a tiger skin? No problem, just open the map and find the area with a big fat tiger stencil on it, then travel to that area and you will find one in no time. Looking for a plant to craft a syringe? Just walk in a straight line and you will find one eventually. There are over a dozen recipes that can be made but only three are helpful and the others are completely useless. Why would I need a syringe that would let me soak damage when the game encourages me to play stealthy?  There are also loot and collectibles, namely statues and letters. All of them appear on the minimap when you get in their vicinity but you can also buy maps that will reveal their locations. Aside from the achievementsthere is no incentive to collect any of them as they will only give you more money. Let's not talk about loot crates, they are countless, and only serves to give even  MORE  money!  Last but not least, FC3 works with a checkpoint system. There is actually 1, yes only 1, save slot, and saving will only save your progress. If you quit and restart the game you will spawn next to the closest radio tower or outpost from your save point. If you want to reload your game try a different strategy be ready to make your way back first. In this day and age this kind of save system is inexcusable.   Pros  : -Wildlife dynamic is so well done that it raises industry standard -Pleasing visuals -Main missions are a blast -A good chunk of achievements feels like achievements   Cons  : -Open world game that doesn't encourage or reward exploration -In-game economy is a joke -Not very challenging -Bland story and dialogue   Final verdict  :  Although I may have seemed harsh I did have a lot of fun playing FC3. Unfortunately the triple-AAA-dification of the franchise is not for the best. The checklist of features might look good on the back of the box but once you scratch the surface their isn't much to be found.  I am actually excited by Ubisoft's upcoming Watchdogs and the almost confirmed FC4, I am anxious to take the journey into their wide open worlds, I just wish they would let go of my hand.   7/10

When I first heard that they were making FarCry3, I was naturally very excited, but somewhat dubious too. I'd bought FarCry when it first came out, and played it to completion. I loved the gameplay and the story, and thought it something really special. Then, when I heard of FarCry 2, I rushed out to relive that same magic, but alas, FarCry 2 was nowhere near as 'fun' to play. Granted, it had nice visuals, handled well, but the constant re-spawning check-points and the whole Malaria storyline got really frustrating. I remember, in fact, giving up about half way through - still not having completed it to this day.   Then, I heard about FarCry 3. Again, it seemed to be a story set on an island, open world, with milita style check points, so I was caught in a quandry - would FarCry 3 be like FarCry 2, or would it actually be fun to play? Well, I'm pleased to admit that I took a chance and bought FarCry 3 - and I'm pleased I did.  I was gripped, from the opening cinematic scenes to the end credits, by the compelling story line and excellent handling. Not only that, but having taken over 45 hours to complete the game, I consider FarCry 3 a perfect example of how fun PC gaming can be. The characters have depth, the voice acting is superb, and the story has a plot that makes many a Hollywood movie seem shallow by comparison. Sure, there may be some (very few) linear moments, but that's coupled with a genuinely 'open world' experience, sub-missions, crafting of kit from scavenged items etc. The choice between a stealth kill and the 'all out guns blazing' approach differs in result and reward, and both can be used on every mission.  In closing, I have to admit that it's not often I actually sit and read the end credits of a game, but this one was worthy of my time and attention. It's been a long time since I enjoyed a game this much, and I sincerely look forward to FarCry 4 - Let's hope they build on the sucess of this game, and not fall back on their laurels.

So. Far Cry 3. The predecessor to Far Cry 4, an amazing game which I have already played and completed. So you might be wondering - is there any point getting this game? Yes. Pros: - Beautiful graphics (even though it's a few years old) - Amazing storyline - you are kidnapped by a psychopatic pirate called Vaas while on a holiday with your two brothers and friends. You then set out to find them and save them using the jungle and cool weapons to help you.  - Weapons - yep, this game might not have such an extensive arsenal of things such as GTA V, but there is enough to keep you happy (especially the special ones such as flamethrowers, and RPG's). - Free Roam/Open World This is one of the best open world games ever. Minimal amounts of people. Lots of nature and wildlife to explore. This makes Far Cry 3 one of the best games ever to just explore.   Cons: Even though this game is simply brilliant, there are still some drawbacks.  - This game does require a good GPU to run it. You will need at least a £130 GPU to play on medium/low settings. So far though with my GTX 770 I have not noticed any frame drops. - Controls This game is best enjoyed with a gamepad which means either getting used to the keyboard or buying a cheap one from ebay or your local dodgy shop. Luckily I have a gamepad.  Also, sometimes you will not know which control is which since this is different than a standard FPS.   And that's about it for the cons. All in all, if you bought this at the sales for peanuts, don't be disappointed because this game is truly fantastic - and even if you didn't, it's still worth the £15 price tag. So I hoped this helped :) P.S I have played this game before, so don't question me playing only 2hrs of it here.
