So I think for me, like alot of people, although I knew about the Far Cry franchise beforehand, Far Cry 3 was my introduction to it. As I came to expect from everything I had heard about it prior to me playing it, the Island setting of the game is absolutely beautiful. One of the highlights of the game is easily either finding a really high mountain or radio tower, or riding a hang glider, and looking off into the distance and seeing the full majesty of the game world, and also realizing that, for the most part, every place you can see is a palce you can go. The gun play, I will admit, is not the most satisfying, but it gets the job done (Although I loved the ripper LMG and the grenade launcher). I did have an awful lot of fun using the bow though, seeing just how far I could get a headshot from, and it was especially fun when you get fire and explosive arrows.   This next paragraph WILL contain spoilers so skip to the next one if you dont want them. Now on the note of the story and characters, the story is pretty much what it seems. You're a group of college students visiting a remote tropical Island which, SURPRISE, is teeming with drug dealing, slave trading, Pirates. In terms of the characters, I found it to be 50/50. Half of the character's SUCK. The main protagonist and his friends are barely tolerable at times with how generic they are. On the other hand, the characters on the Islands themselves, are actually pretty well done. You can tell they put alot of effort into the villains, and holy crap, Vaas is probably one of the best villains ever. He balances both humor and sadism perfectly, and I think it's kind of lame he wasn't really the main villain of the game. Now one HUGE gripe I have with the game is the ending (or endings). Basically in a sense, the game really tries to make you pick a certain choice. If you choose to stay on the Island with Citra, the game punishes you for it in several ways, and that just sort of kills it for me and makes me wonder why they even bothered giving you the option.  The game does actually do a reasonably good job of making you feel like you're out of your element, trying to survive on this remote Island........for awhile at least. Early on, the practice of hunting, gathering, exploring and activating radio towers to reveal the island and gain new supplies and weapons, the bounty and hunting misslons, searching for relics, and taking pirate outposts really to feeling of trying to survive....but once you get past a certain point, it starts to feel like busy work. Once you have all the weapons, activating all the towers, and taken all the out posts, there isn't much of a point to doing anything else and not finishing the game.  Ultimately, I did enjoy my time with Far Cry 3, and although it certainly isn't one of my favorite FPSs ever, I think anyone who enjoys open world games will find something to enjoy here. Get it when it's on sale.

Now, going into this game, I had many misconceptions about the Far Cry series in general, and to be honest I didn't expect too much from this game. Well, as it turns out, I was quite mistaken. Sure, the main character sucks, and sure pretty much everybody on Rook Island (Including him) are villanous to some capacity, but the game is fantastic. The setting is a small set of islands in the South Pacific, where you, and your brothers and friends, are taken captive by Vaas Montenegro, an unhinged pirate who revels in his insanity. In fact, it could be argued that he's the most sane of the villans since he acknowedges his mental state. But I digress. So, you're lucky enough to escape the slave trade, and declare a one-man war against Vaas and his pirates. The environment is not exactly varied, mostly what one would expect in an equitorial climate. Beach and jungle, with some mountains and old temple ruins thrown in for variety. The gameplay is fantastic. There is nothing as thrilling as mowing down pirates responding to an SOS call because you failed stealth to the tune of some odd dubstep/drums and bass track. The soundtrack is fantastic. It alternates between the former, and a quiet, pounding stealth track that plays whenever you silently dispatch pirates to gain access to their base. In this game, stealth is as much of an option as loud, and in fact I feel it is as fun, but have no fear. There are plenty of weapons to suit your needs should things not go as planned. Between the heart-pounding soundtrack, the variety of guns (go with the AK) and the option to do pretty much anything you want, any way you want, and the villan to end all villans, and I cannot see why you shouldn't play this game. Even if you like more futuristic FPS games (Like me) and you don't like the idea of slicing some pirate up with a machete in a hot, sweaty jungle, trust me; You'll be glad you did. In all honesty, I want Far cry 4 to be as good as Far Cry 3, but I don't know; the bar's been set almost impossibly high. Overall Score: 10/10

First off, let me say that while I have 100 hours recorded playing this game, there probably isnt near that much content. I experienced the notorious 'invisible walls' glitch, whereby my character would inexplicably stop and be unable to proceed forward, as though there was a wall in front of him, although nothing actually appeared on the screen. It took quite a bit of manipulating the movement keys, alternately crouching or standing up, backing off and running forward, and other such tricks to find the window to allow me to proceed. As such, climbing radio towers required quite an investment of time, hence the hours I racked up playing.  However, from the online search I did it seems that only a small minority of players experience this glitch, and even with it this game was immensely enjoyable. The designers did an exceptional job in not forcing you to play the game a certain way. You can achieve most of the objectives any way you like. So, if your prefernce is to stand off at a distance and dispatch opponents with silenced sniper rifles and bow shots you can do that. Alternately, you can sneak in and take opponents by stealth at close quarters. Or you could charge in guns blazing and blow everything up. Any of those methods will work.  The main story line is well done and proceeds at the right pace, without making you feel like its dictating yoru actions. There is lots to do on the island outside the main plot. You can search for relics, lost letters from Japanese servicemen stationed on the island during WWII, engage in races with all sorts of vehicles from boats to dune buggys to ATVs. Take a hangglider ride. Play some poker. Like I said lots to do.  My machine is pretty slow so I played the game on the lowets graphics settings and it still looked good to me, but Ive never put much emphasis on graphics so your opinion may be different.  All in all, and excellent FPS with a good stroy and excellent game design. Well worth adding to your games library, especially when it is on sale for less than $5.

Far Cry 3 is the king of aesthetics. The jungles scattered throughout the island are overflowing with detail, wildlife, etc. The game does a great job at having you feel immersed as you try to save your friends from an unforgiving warlord, and his henchmen. The first few hours of the game are bliss. You're just killing things, and getting tatt'ed up. The game then becomes stale. Don't buy this game. The story is terribly written in my opinion and doesnt fit at all in the far cry series. the gameplay is very repetetive, with each outpost having the same structure. it comes too predicable that even at the hardest difficulty you can easily do well at the game just using a pistol.   In the story (Both co-op and single player) it's just cliche after cliche after cliche. It happens so often that it just gets annoying and it just feels awful. You get no connection to the protagonist at all, you won't llike him, you don't even want to be him and wish he'd just jump off a cliff, break his ankles and left there for no one to be found ever. Neither do you feel connected to the world. In most games you get a sense of where you are, roads feel familiar, certain parts feel like home. In this game it is just jungle after beach after dirt road and they all just seem the same.  The story is full of spiritual nonsense that could fit in a setting centuries ago or in a different kind of world (where magic and unicorns exist), but not in the 21-st century on a tropical island where everybody has 17 guns. If you have a gun, you don't need some pretentious spiritual power to kill just another thug with a group of his guards. Honestly, the only way the game is fun is to just avoid all storyline missions, not using the map and running around blindly shooting people. Basically what Far Cry 2 consisted of.  The co-op is kind of alright in the game. The campaign doesnt really have that much story (this doesn't really matter though, it's about shooting things with your friends). It consists of multiple chapters which can be played chronologically. It's fun to do a few times, but the problem is that all these chapters are so repetetive and contain the same things, you never get a nice surprise. The worst part is the extreme glitchiness in Co-op. Anybody has a ping over 60? Fat chance that when you respawn after everyone dies, somebody on your team will just randomly drop dead and has to wait for the next checkpoint. Say goodbye to your progress.  All in all, get off the store page, and spend your money on a better game. But not this, don't do this to yourself.

I was really looking forward to a CryTek-powered open world shooter. What I got was a dirty needle and some pig entrails. This is a disgusting game in more than one way. Obviously, there's a crafting system that involves gutting and skinning animals that you hunt. It's gross and I can get past that. That's not the disgusting that bothers me. The enemies are pretty rough characters -- drug runners, kidnappers and mercenaries. Looting them will yield an assortment of colorful vendor fodder like dirty needles, crackpipes and the sort. This bothers me a bit...but I can get past it. The game, however, seems to pride itself in what an ugly world and situation it places you in. Loading screens treat you with random, stream-of-consciousness words, a few of which are obscenities. Of course the in-game dialog is repleat with obscenities. I guess you can't have a modern 'gritty' game without them. At this point, I'm swallowing a lot of ugly for the sake of the game play, which holds up pretty well until you start hitting certain progression walls.  Like many games claiming to be open worlds, the world is gradually revealed or unlocked through progression in the story. Character skills and crafting recipes are similarly locked to your storyline. In the end, it was these restrictions that put me off to the game entirely. I hated the storyline for the game's ugliness I described above. I just didn't want to run through it. However, with at least half of the game world locked away behind irritating game content, I lost my will to play the game at all. And cheat codes don't help you much in escort missions in which NPCs will gladly take cover in front of enemy gunfire.  All of that said, I laud CryTek for what they tried to do here -- open world shooting with crafting and skill systems that feel lifted from the latest MMO. I loved that concept. I just wish it weren't tied to content that made me feel worse for playing the game.

This is a long overdue review that I should have published last year after playing the game:  I pre-purchased and pre-loaded this game at full price. I was so disappointed in the game that I felt like I wasted the $60 I paid. The game itself seemed to be quite buggy and it even prevented me from playing it at full quality. Due to the fact that I have ATI drivers and not Nvidia, the game itself would not go over 15-25 frames at a resolution of 1600x900 on low quality.  When this game came out I was playing BF3 and Max Payne 3 at ultra settings getting 45-60 frames. There was no reason that this game should have been performing as terribly as it was.   I even contacted Ubisoft customer support to resolve the issue I was having. All they told me was the typical stuff such as update drivers etc. I had already done the basics and they couldn't offer more help except to casually claim there would be an update soon. It was an update that never came. The game was s*** and you guys obviously didn't care. All you cared about was raking in the cash while you could. ATI users were screwed and it was plain to see that it was just an overall bad port to PC. Just like the recent Watch_Dogs, lots of PC users were left sitting with a game that didn't operate up to the specs they claimed originally.   Now let's talk about the multiplayer. What was that trash? Attempting to create a fun or at least competitive multiplayer seemed none existant. The multiplayer probably should have been left out of this shiny gem. The map editor was fun, thanks for allowing me to make maps for a terrible multiplayer. Far Cry 2 wasn't the greatest but at least it was broken like the multiplayer and coop was for 3. And coop was not necessary at all. Again it was attempted to make a competitive/fun coop by allowing up to 4 players to run amuk. The only problem was the coop was close to being a rail shooter due to how linear it was setup. Making an 'open world' game closed for coop was probably one of the dumber decisions you could have made in this game.  [Spoilers ahead] So the story you guys made, it was okay I guess. It had some merits but some of it seemed quite childish and silly mostly. You play a typical white guy who despite his stupid rich friends seems to be able to pick up any gun and just blow away the baddies like it's no big deal at all. Later some how you become the leader of a bunch of islanders and start a revolution, while also tripping major balls on drugs and fighting weird tiki monsters that look absolutely ridiculous. Oh and let's not forget all the while this story is happening you are killing hundreds of endangered species and taking their hides to make a bigger wallet to store the money you take off the bodies of the hundreds of mercs you laid waste to. If you weren't busy skinning a giant helpless tortoise or gliding around oddly placed japanese bunkers you were likely blowing up outpost after outpost slowly boring yourself to death. Overall the story seemed way far fetched and just ridiculous. Who will you choose at the end? Your stupid rich friends, or your new crazy islander wackos. The choice is up to you bucko! Oh boy it's over, thank you!  So to conclude my review of this game. Thank you for a bad port to PC, again. Thank you for not catering to all drivers in the PC gaming world, again. And lastly thank you for wasting $60 of my hard earned money, again.

Racist ♥♥♥ video game. Okay, maybe you won't really agree that the game has some race problems like I do, but at the very least, I didn't care at all about the main characters which is kind of a huge issue. I don't mind a heart of darkness retelling, actually in fact I love them, Spec Ops: The Line for instance is an incredible game and does this similar kind of story in all the right ways. Far Cry 3, however, feels like the story and missions were the almgamation of many different studios with different ideas that don't all quite fit, for instance a pretty hefty part of the game is spent trying to find a knife with supernatural like properties but then you never really do anything with it, leading me to think that Far Cry 3 may have at one time had a more realistic supernatual element to it like the Tomb Raider games.   I suppose the shooting was actually quite good but it wasn't that much of an improvement over Far Cry 2, and I did have some fun playing it some of the time, but I just couldn't get invested in the action going on because I didn't care at all about what was going on or what what was happening to the characters. My biggest issue in gameplay is that it never feels rewarding and often feels too much of a chore and I'm someone who grinded like no other in WoW and other games so this was a huge issue for me.  And I guess you could say, 'well it isn't about the story it is about exploring around and exploding stuff.' Okay sure, I don't agree because I think this game is trying to tonally be a story heavy game, but If I were to accept that I think there is a lot of problems making a game playing a priveleged, wealthy white dude that finds it fun to kill scores of brown people in a developing, war-striffed country and while I did have fun with some of the shooting this was something that I kept thinking of in the back of my mind. It's not that you should have sympathy for the people he is kiling because they are pirates in human trafficing and drug trade. But, it is the fact that it was made by design to have the primary villians be people of color and you can only play as a wealthy, white dude.  I would be okay with racist elements, meaning I would still think they are racist, if the game was still enjoyable and redeamable in other aspects but the other aspects, I thought, were 'just okay' making the game not recomendable.  TL:DR It's okay. But, not good enough.

This game is incredibly unpolished and not worth anybody's time. The crafting aspect is just a gimmick to inconvenience the player for about 4 hours, and then quickly just becomes an awkward way to generate syringes (medkits). The entire UI is obviously a quick port from consoles- terribly clunky. The protagonist's hitbox feels like a large rectangle that barely fits on any staircase- I literally spend 10-30 seconds trying to get on a staircase.   Slightly uneven floors gets you stuck, and sometimes it seemed that corpses did it too- maybe the controls are just unresponsive. On the note of unresponsive controls, the RPG-7 is a great example. After reloading then ADS, there is a good 2 seconds where the game refuses to let you fire. The inconsistency with takedown prompts makes the cool knifing sequences not worth it- easier to just gun people down with a silenced weapon. AI is dumb as three sacks of bricks at a potato salad factory. The difficulty only seems to make you die faster, and Master (Very Hard), is not Very Hard. Only 'hard' part of the game is when it throws you into situations that your current loadout is not good for, and you are too lazy to restart the mission.  I've died more times falling from radio towers than from guns. The whole radio tower climbing thing is horribly annoying and not enjoyable whatsoever. The devs must have confused Far Cry 3 with Rock Climbing Simulator 1990. Every uneven surface will get you stuck, and unwanted vaulting animations will make your character joyfully leap to his death. Whole radio tower ordeal seems like a rip from Assassin's Creed. Too bad Ubisoft didn't also add free climbing so the whole thing didn't suck. No persistent Load Last Save option shows that this game lacks features that even the original Halo had.  Only completed this game so that I would never have to come back to it. Last note: lots of unskippable cutscenes. Quick-time events often restart you before a unskippable cutscene. Good recipe for fun. Even Battlefield 3 knows not to restart the player at the beginning of cutscenes when restarting a failed quick-time event.   3/10 Looks pretty. But, just play Far Cry 2 instead.

While this game is well ported with a natural control scheme and graphics that run smoothly the game it's self is lacking. Sure on the surface there is plenty to do. In fact in order to 'level' your character you actually have to do a variety of different open world missions in order to earn xp, and more importantly upgrade your weapon and ammo capacity. That's a great way to make the players engage the open world that you have created. From that perspective alone the game is fun. Though there are some annoyances with scripted events spawning guys after you shot everyone else in that area which is annoying cause you think you've cleared it out already. The driving controls are bad. I'd rather just walk everywhere then use a vehicle if I can. Being able to sneak around the jungle is cool. Where the game really falls apart is the 'good guy' side of the character cast. How you ask? Let's meet the characters. *SOME SPOILERS AHEAD*  First up is token black guy with generic foreign accent. Could be Islander, Jamaican, African or Finnish, who knows, it's terrible. Then he wears a US Marine button down because he was in America and/or in the US military but had to leave because he was a bad cab driver or something? I don't know. He is such an odd character that by the time he opens up about his “mysterious past” in the story I'm at the point where I don't care, just tell me what I have to do for the quest. He teaches you the whole time about the power of the tattoo/tat-tau and being a warrior and how it saved him from being a lost soul. Except he never does anything warrior like and is a total train wreck emotionally the entire game. He's like Lord Friend Zone from Game of Thrones except LFZ has his stuff together and actually does stuff. This guy just mopes around his hut all day trying to give you tattoos and ♥♥♥♥♥es at you on the radio because you aren't saving the entire island single handily fast enough.  Then comes the generic cast of native islander people. Who are covered from taint to septum in tattoo which are suppose to be earned and represent bad-assery except that these guys literally help you do nothing. They can't even take a single out post by themselves nor seem to do anything other then occasionally get into horrible car accidents while driving around for no reason instead of helping you fight the pirate occupiers. Thank God Chad, the generic frat bro comes along to rescue them from their own inept misery. Doing so by learning about their bad ♥♥♥ warrior culture which they themselves can't seem to harness for their own good.  Finally you meet the warrior-goddess-priestess chick who leads the physical and spiritual rebellion against the pirate/slaver MNC? She happens of course to be the one hot chick on the entire island chain who advances your warrior training by swinging her hips around seductively. Gets you broodingly to do rando missions that finally result in her roofieing you and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you. But you don't seem to mind cause she's hot, even though you have a girlfriend? And because you finally sleep with her she and because of her major cracker-jack fever, she goes all psyco-girlfriend on you and forces you to choose between her and your actual girlfriend. One of which will be your sex toy war prize for winning the other will be brutalized and killed. Wonderful.  Finally there is the cast of generic frat bros and sorority sis's who you came to the island with. Regardless of relationship to you they all are at times incredible weak (this is understandable they are very traumatized from being captured by human slavers) to incredibly strong like killing people and flying helicopters. Then snap back to being really weak again, brooding and definitely on their moral high horse because you're 'questionably' killing people while being a bad ♥♥♥ and saving them from being sex slaves. On top of all the whinny-ness the one who is your girlfriend, once saved, gets all weird because you're showing strength and resolve by saving a repressed island from the sex trafficking trade and from a life of slavery at the hands of pirates. She seems to prefer and does her best to push you back from warrior crusader, who is fighting for good, to Chad who lives off daddy's allowance while drinking bud light on the couch of the families third vacation home all day. Also she immediately starts planning your life for you again after you rescue her? Super annoying.   Now the story is saved by two incredibly well written bad guys whose monologues and character interactions are amazingly entertaining and you truly feel a sense of both anger at them for their actions, but a sense of justification in their own actions in their insanity and evilness. They see what they are doing as both bettering the economy of the island and bringing a better life along with all the corruption. They make naturally unlikable bad guys with out being too cliche.   The CIA officer and his German mercenary friend are also both very entertaining and lend well to the story.  The game is worth it on sale. But the weak female characters, whose soul purpose in the story is to be prize objects annoyed me. Especially since one is suppose to be a warrior priestess who like voodoo-tattoo lord friend zone really never does anything worthy of the title warrior. I don't think either of them can even actually use a weapon. They could have done so much more with the story. Either by simply leaving some of these characters out, or by making their contributions to the story more meaningful and less weak. In the end it feels like we are just left with a tale where white frat boy Chad comes and saves his weak bros and some brown people by becoming a brooding emotionally scarred PTSD Rambo who machine guns his way through an entire Black Water battalion of pirate slavers. And it could have been more of that as an action style movie/game with less weak characters, or less of that with more of a cast of strong supporting characters who support the main character's growth as a warrior and as a person.

First off, let me say that I have played this game on XBox 360 before, and it was absolutely briliant, however there are a few things on the PC version that make me not recomment this game...   Negative  Okay, so I got this game against my better judgement (one word: UPlay), since it was on sale. While steam does state that a UPlay account is required, I assumed it wouldn't be  that bad . After you install the game, you will have to make a uplay acount and activate the game on uplay, after which it then looks for updates. Technically, this would be it, you are good to go and play the game....  ...except:    Every time you want to play the game you have to launch uplay. Yes, every time. Not just once 'to activate', but  every. single. time.  *sigh*    Let's say you like to play in offline mode. Or you don't have internet (yes that is a thing, unfortionately not everyone is lucky enough to have the privilege of an always-on internet connection) then you can play Farcry 3, you can even set Uplay to launch in 'offline mode'. This however does not stop Farcry from trying to connect to the Ubisoft servers whenever you press ESC. If it cannot connect, you do not get the option to press some sort of 'connect' button, but instead the game just retries the next time you enter the menu.    Savgames. For me, the savegame backup function of Uplay didn't work, resulting in me losing my saves. While this might be down to my own internet speeds, firewall setup/whatever-other-thing-you-can-think-of, the problem is trying to restore savegames. Other peoples savegames to be exact.  Normally, when you loose your savegame, you either start the game from scratch, or you download a savegame from the internet. Well, you guessed it, Ubisoft won't let you. For whatever reason you are not able to install someone else's savegame anymore (apparently you used to be able to do that, but not anymore). I tried, I failed, and I've given up...    Positive  Now, if I just ignore the technical faults of this game, I can still think of plenty of good reasons (as tempting as it is to just vent my frustration)  Now, let me say that I don't really know much about what is considered good or bad graphics, but I think it's safe to say that Farcry 3 has some pretty decent graphics. And as a bonus, it even supports borderless fullscreen mode! (More games should have that, easier to Alt-Tab that way...)  The Story of Farcry 3 was pretty good, and I still think that this is one of the few games that really manages to get the concept of character development accross. You start off as a 'normal dude' and, well...I don't really want to spoil the story, but you really get to feel Jason's emotions and thoughts. The first time Jason kills someone for example, he's not just 'meh, just another NPC' but he is actually shocked. I can't really put it into words, but this is one of the things the game does well.  Next: Music. The game features some background music everytime you drive a vehicle, which is pretty nice. Not as immersive as the radio stations found in games like GTA or Sleeping dogs, but still a pretty nice touch. They also fit in with the whole Tropical-Island-Theme. That's not all though. For me personally, there were two instances when the music was just perfect in every way. The first being when you go around in a flamethrower (trust me, you'll know which mission I mean) and near the end of the game, a mission involving escaping in a helicopter (again, you'll know which mission). You can drive cars and boats, fly using gliders and swim and dive. The entire game is open world as well, which makes it that much more fun. There are a lot of things to discover like caves, hiding secret relics or crashed planes where letters of long-dead soldiers can be found. Weapons can also be customized both in ability (more ammo, better aiming and the like) as well as in appearance (using pre-defined color schemes you can select). In addition to this there are also a lot of skills you can learn and things you can craft. To craft, animals must be hunted and plants collected. The game's length is alright, but it can be extended if you bother to collect some relics or go explore every now and then.    Overall, yes it is a good game, however this is a PC, and the reason many of us are playing it on PC is because they do not want to put up with all the negative aspects of consoles. This means being able to use your own savegame files, no mater where you got them from! In addition to this, I am puzzled why steam would sell a game that basically just launches another marketplace that is trying to compete with steam... Thats like taking a BMW for a test drive just to drive to your local Mercedes dealer...  Even though I myself will think twice before buying anything from Ubisoft again, I tried to write this review as fairly and nicely as possible. Hopefully it is somewhat balanced.

It's a heavily over cliched trawl through the same tasks over and over e.g. activate tower, capture outpost, do side quests and look for relics & lost letters, next tower, capture outpost etc.  Some reviewers have spoken about the open world play. What open world play? Once you have a map area cleared what is there left to do? Stand in a field and take a pop shot at animals?  What irks me most though is this game has absolutely no originalty and there was just a sense of boredom playing it, the terrain doesn't even change for example. The devs have a chance of creating an open world full of possibilities and they just deliver a linear story which isn't immersive or fun in any way.  If you're looking to buy this, even on a sale then don't bother. Do yourself a favour and get Just Cause 2 or 3. Similar story line and similar environment bu JC2 is great fun. Come on, who doesn't like hijacking a helicopter, taking it to the nearest base/oil rig/etc and just going to town on it. It's good fun.  Far Cry 3 Cons: * Boring unbelievable story. How does 1 tourist take over a series of islands that a whole army of tribal warriors couldn't? * Main character (Jason Brody) could do with a slap * Monotonous terrain * Keystrokes take an age to activate e.g. hold q to heal, by the time that kicks in you're dead * The local animals are just a hinderance e.g. in the middle of a fire fight, a tiger comes in and kills you * Repetitious game play * Not enough modes of transport  Pros: * Can't think of any
